If 2 neutron ports for same instance belongs to one device_group
they would scheduled to different PFs. Extend pci device spec to
know about 'dev_group' and 'forbidden_ips'.
Change in nova.pci.devspec was done to follow 'phys_function' to
nova.pci.utils.pci_device_prop_match()

Part of bp: libvirt-sriov-nic-bonding

Change-Id: Ibd696fbcb55e9c39a0fb6dcfd72b479422b8eb9e
"}, {'created': '2015-01-23 14:13:04.000000000', 'message': "Allocate 2 neutron ports to different PFs

If 2 neutron ports for same instance belongs to one device_group
they would scheduled to different PFs. Extend pci device spec to
know about 'dev_group' and 'forbidden_fps'.
Change in nova.pci.devspec was done to follow 'phys_function' to
nova.pci.utils.pci_device_prop_match()

Part of bp: libvirt-sriov-nic-bonding

Change-Id: Ibd696fbcb55e9c39a0fb6dcfd72b479422b8eb9e
"}]
commit_message:
Allocate 2 neutron ports to different PFs

If 2 neutron ports for same instance belongs to one device_group
they would scheduled to different PFs. Extend pci device spec to
know about 'dev_group' and 'forbidden_fps'.
Change in nova.pci.devspec was done to follow 'phys_function' to
nova.pci.utils.pci_device_prop_match()

Part of bp: libvirt-sriov-nic-bonding

Change-Id: Ibd696fbcb55e9c39a0fb6dcfd72b479422b8eb9e

[{'created': '2015-02-10 08:45:52.000000000', 'message': "Scheduler support for neutron ports' dev_group

Make PciDeviceStats.suport_requests method, that is used by
scheduler to determine if a host could meet the PCI requests
requirements, respect Neutron's port 'dev_group' attribute
that requires VFs for neutron ports corresponding to the same
device group to be placed on different PFs.

Also, update objects.PciDevice.create() method not to strip
additional information from the device, such as 'extra_info',
that contains an address of the physical function and we need that
for unit tests.

Part of bp: libvirt-sriov-nic-bonding

Change-Id: I24d77734239557ee9ea8cfd77690b3fbc28542f4
"}]
commit_message:
Scheduler support for neutron ports' dev_group

Make PciDeviceStats.suport_requests method, that is used by
scheduler to determine if a host could meet the PCI requests
requirements, respect Neutron's port 'dev_group' attribute
that requires VFs for neutron ports corresponding to the same
device group to be placed on different PFs.

Also, update objects.PciDevice.create() method not to strip
additional information from the device, such as 'extra_info',
that contains an address of the physical function and we need that
for unit tests.

Part of bp: libvirt-sriov-nic-bonding

Change-Id: I24d77734239557ee9ea8cfd77690b3fbc28542f4

subject: Libvirt: Make ImageCacheManager use a Storage Pool

commit_message:
Libvirt: Make ImageCacheManager use a Storage Pool

This commit changes the libvirt driver's ImageCacheManager to
use a libvirt storage pool and the related APIs to manage the
image cache.  This paves the way for a libvirt-storage-pool-based
image backend, as libvirt will properly copy and convert images
when copying between storage pools.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: Id8f8fce184cd78d5cb03b586e715634265ec6803

Note: this is an optional patch in the sense that this can be removed, and logic similar to the legacy backend (convert to raw, resize, convert to qcow2) could be inserted into the next patch.  However, since libvirt doesn't have a "rename" command, there's a bit of extra overhead, and I figured since we already launch a libguestfs instance when running is_image_partitionless in the legacy resize code for qcow2, it makes more sense just to use that libguestfs instance.'}, {'account_id': 7677, 'date': '2015-01-21 17:00:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7677, 'date': '2015-01-21 18:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-21 20:25:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-21 01:16:55.000000000', 'message': 'Support Resizing and Checking Filesystems with VFS

This commit adds support for checking and resizing filesystems
on COW imagesusing a VFS.  This replaces the support for using
a mounter (since the VFS will either us libguestfs or a mounter
anyway) and is still behind the same config option.

Since we already spin up a VFS instance when running
is_image_partitionless, is_image_partitionless has been
refactored to take an optional `if_so` argument.  If `if_so`
is specified, it will be run when the image has been determined
to be partitionless.  However, when testing COW images, `if_so`
will be called before the VFS is shut down, with the VFS instance
as the second argument to `if_so`, allowing us to reused the existing
VFS instead.

This can be used to avoid cases like the libvirt driver qcow2 resize
code, which first converts the image from qcow2 to raw, operates
on it, and then converts back.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: Icec7e6cfc834b438b06318b3d31e71d9197178e0

commit_message:
Disk/VFS: Support Check/Resize with VFS

This commit adds support for checking and resizing filesystems
on COW imagesusing a VFS.  This replaces the support for using
a mounter (since the VFS will either us libguestfs or a mounter
anyway) and is still behind the same config option.

Since we already spin up a VFS instance when running
is_image_partitionless, is_image_partitionless has been
refactored to take an optional `if_so` argument.  If `if_so`
is specified, it will be run when the image has been determined
to be partitionless.  However, when testing COW images, `if_so`
will be called before the VFS is shut down, with the VFS instance
as the second argument to `if_so`, allowing us to reused the existing
VFS instead.

This can be used to avoid cases like the libvirt driver qcow2 resize
code, which first converts the image from qcow2 to raw, operates
on it, and then converts back.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: Icec7e6cfc834b438b06318b3d31e71d9197178e0

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-08-15 15:17:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

As a general point I think there is *faaar* to much going on in this patch.  I've spent alot of time looking at the code and I very little confidence that I've even remotely identified all the problems.  A big thing I'm struggling with is that there is alot of refactoring of existing logic taking place, in parallel with the actual introduction of the new storage pool concept. As it is structured now I'm  going to struggle to ever have the confidence to +2 it.

I'd really like to see this patch split upto into a bunch more patches. Do as much of the refactoring as possible as independant patches, with the aim that the final step simply drops in the new storage pool class to imagebackend.py and does not need to touch anything else."}, {'account_id': 7677, 'date': '2014-08-18 21:13:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(11 comments)

(see inline comments)

WRT splitting this patch into multiple parts, it's difficult, since I was lead to believe that each patch must be fully functional on its own.  Most of this patch is not, in fact, refactoring existing code, but is instead changing existing code to support the libvirt storage backend. [{'created': '2014-08-09 03:56:45.000000000', 'message': "Introduce the Libvirt Storage Image Backend

This commit introduces the libvirt storage image backend.
For this commit, the backend will only be used if an image
type of 'libvirt-storage' is specified.  The libvirt
ImageCacheManager has also been made aware of how to extract
the backing file path of a libvirt-storage-backed VM.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: I73aa1fcd301c254f20614b38115f880e79e15c7c

"}, {'created': '2014-08-26 18:16:04.000000000', 'message': "Introduce the Libvirt Storage Image Backend

This commit introduces the libvirt storage image backend.
For this commit, the backend will only be used if an image
type of 'libvirt-storage' is specified.  The libvirt
ImageCacheManager has also been made aware of how to extract
the backing file path of a libvirt-storage-backed VM.

In order to facilitate cold migrations and resizes, migrate data
is now passed to the destroy method on revert-resize containing
information on whether or not we are resizing to the same host.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: I73aa1fcd301c254f20614b38115f880e79e15c7c

'[libvirt] use_storage_pools' option is enabled.  The libvirt
ImageCacheManager has also been made aware of how to extract
the backing file path of a libvirt-storage-backed VM.

In order to facilitate cold migrations and resizes, migrate data
is now passed to the destroy method on revert-resize containing
information on whether or not we are resizing to the same host.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

"}, {'created': '2014-09-05 21:04:46.000000000', 'message': "Introduce the Libvirt Storage Image Backend

This commit introduces the libvirt storage image backend.
For this commit, the backend will only be used if the
'[libvirt] use_storage_pools' option is enabled.  The libvirt
ImageCacheManager has also been made aware of how to extract
the backing file path of a libvirt-storage-backed VM.

If no pool of the appropriate name exists, a pool will be created
based the legacy backend configuration options.

In order to facilitate cold migrations and resizes, migrate data
is now passed to the destroy method on revert-resize containing
information on whether or not we are resizing to the same host.

Note that RBD-based storage pools are not yet supported.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: I73aa1fcd301c254f20614b38115f880e79e15c7c
"}, {'created': '2014-09-06 03:15:20.000000000', 'message': "Introduce the Libvirt Storage Image Backend

ImageCacheManager has also been made aware of how to extract
the backing file path of a libvirt-storage-backed VM.

If no pool of the appropriate name exists, a pool will be created
based the legacy backend configuration options.

In order to facilitate cold migrations and resizes, migrate data
is now passed to the destroy method on revert-resize containing
information on whether or not we are resizing to the same host.

Note that RBD-based storage pools are not yet supported.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: I73aa1fcd301c254f20614b38115f880e79e15c7c
"}, {'created': '2014-09-06 04:14:35.000000000', 'message': "Introduce the Libvirt Storage Image Backend

This commit introduces the libvirt storage image backend.
For this commit, the backend will only be used if the
'[libvirt] use_storage_pools' option is enabled.  The libvirt
ImageCacheManager has also been made aware of how to extract
the backing file path of a libvirt-storage-backed VM.

If no pool of the appropriate name exists, a pool will be created
based the legacy backend configuration options.

In order to facilitate cold migrations and resizes, migrate data

This commit introduces the libvirt storage image backend.

'[libvirt] use_storage_pools' option is enabled.  The libvirt
ImageCacheManager has also been made aware of how to extract
the backing file path of a libvirt-storage-backed VM.

If no pool of the appropriate name exists, a pool will be created
based the legacy backend configuration options.

In order to facilitate cold migrations and resizes, migrate data
is now passed to the destroy method on revert-resize containing
information on whether or not we are resizing to the same host.

Note that RBD-based storage pools are not yet supported.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

commit_message:
Introduce the Libvirt Storage Image Backend

This commit introduces the libvirt storage image backend.
For this commit, the backend will only be used if the
'[libvirt] use_storage_pools' option is enabled.  The libvirt
ImageCacheManager has also been made aware of how to extract
the backing file path of a libvirt-storage-backed VM.

If no pool of the appropriate name exists, a pool will be created
based the legacy backend configuration options.

In order to facilitate cold migrations and resizes, migrate data
is now passed to the destroy method on revert-resize containing
information on whether or not we are resizing to the same host.

Note that RBD-based storage pools are not yet supported.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: I73aa1fcd301c254f20614b38115f880e79e15c7c

[{'created': '2014-10-26 17:57:47.000000000', 'message': 'VMWare - Support for video memory to instances

This patch supports the feature of video memory, multiple displays
and 3D support for instances spawned using VMWare driver.

The video memory can be set in flavor using the following
nova flavor-key <flavor-id> set hw_video:video_ram
                                   =<size of video ram>

The number of displays for the instance can be set using
the following
nova flavor-key <flavor-id> set hw_video:video_display
                                 =<num_of_displays>

The support for video memory and number of displays is
provided in both spawn and resize operations

The 3D support for the instance can be set in the image property using
glance image-update --property enable3dsupport=True <image-uuid>

3D support needs to be set only in image as this is image specific
settings (For ex: Windows 8 image can have 3D support)

Co-Authored-By: K M, Bharath Kumar <bharath.k-m@hp.com>

Change-Id: Ib34856d1d25349994689d36e47579a3325e61500
Implements: blueprint vmware-driver-support-for-video-memory

commit_message:
VMWare - Support for video memory to instances

This patch supports the feature of video memory, multiple displays
and 3D support for instances spawned using VMWare driver.

The video memory can be set in flavor using the following
nova flavor-key <flavor-id> set hw_video:video_ram
                                   =<size of video ram>

The number of displays for the instance can be set using
the following
nova flavor-key <flavor-id> set hw_video:video_display
                                 =<num_of_displays>

The support for video memory and number of displays is
provided in both spawn and resize operations.

This patch supports only spawn. A subsequent patch will
support resize operation

3D Support can be set to an instance only if both image and flavor
contain 3D support.
This is done to ensure that instances can have 3D support only
if the admin allows such instances.

The 3D support for the instance can be set in the image property using
glance image-update --property hw_video_3d=True <image-uuid>

The 3D support in flavor can be set using
nova flavor-key <flavor-id> set hw_video:video_3d

Co-Authored-By: K M, Bharath Kumar <bharath.k-m@hp.com>

DocImpact
The docs should describe how the video memory, number of
displays and 3D support can be set in flavor and how 3D support can be set
in image properties. Examples for all the 3 provided above
Change-Id: Ib34856d1d25349994689d36e47579a3325e61500
Implements: blueprint vmware-driver-support-for-video-memory

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2067, 'date': '2014-12-24 14:27:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Hi Sylvain,

As mentioned in the commit message and in the BP https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vmware-video-memory-filter-scheduler

VMWare vCenter does not provide any API for returning free Video Memory.
Also the default behavior of vCenter is to allocate video memory on Host RAM if the video memory cannot be allocated on Hardware GPU.
Also even if hardware GPU is available, only half of the requested video memory is stored on hardware GPU and the other half on host RAM. This is the default behavior of vCenter.
Hence performing this filter calculation

-- Sagar'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2015-01-05 13:39:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-11-01 17:12:39.000000000', 'message': 'VMWare Video Memory Filter

This patch provides a filter scheduler for performing
calculations using video memory.

Support for video memory for VMWare instances is
in review.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/130988/

The video memory allocation in vCenter  is evenly divided
- Half the video memory is reserved on the hardware GPU,
  while the other half is reserved via host RAM.

if however video memory is not available on hardware GPU,
the vCenter sets the video memory on host RAM

The vCenter does not provide any API which returns
the free video memory on the hardware GPU.
Hence when a instance requires video memory,
the scheduler calculation for a valid host can happen
on the free host memory since vCenter by default uses
host memory if video memory on hardware GPU is not available.

This patch adds the video memory to the requested RAM
for performs the scheduler calculation

Co-Authored-By: K M, Bharath Kumar <bharath.k-m@hp.com>

DocImpact

'}, {'created': '2014-11-10 12:13:37.000000000', 'message': 'Video Memory Filter

This patch provides a filter scheduler for performing
calculations using video memory.

This patch started as a filter specific to VMWare driver.
However the filter has been changed to make it more generic
based on review comments.

If any hypervisor allocates video memory either partly or fully
on the host memory, then this filter can be used for
scheduler calculations.

Behaviour of VMWare vCenter for video memory allocation ---

The video memory allocation in vCenter  is evenly divided
- Half the video memory is reserved on the hardware GPU,
  while the other half is reserved via host RAM.

if however video memory is not available on hardware GPU,
the vCenter sets the video memory on host RAM

The vCenter does not provide any API which returns
the free video memory on the hardware GPU.
Hence when a instance requires video memory,
the scheduler calculation for a valid host can happen
on the free host memory since vCenter by default uses
host memory if video memory on hardware GPU is not available.

This patch adds the video memory to the requested RAM
for performs the scheduler calculation.

The filter is generic and can be used by any other hypervisors
which have a similar behaviour

Support for video memory for VMWare instances is
in review.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/130988/

commit_message:
Video Memory Filter

This patch provides a filter scheduler for performing
calculations using video memory.

If any hypervisor allocates video memory either partly or fully
on the host memory, then this filter can be used for
scheduler calculations.

Behaviour of VMWare vCenter for video memory allocation ---

The video memory allocation in vCenter  is evenly divided
- Half the video memory is reserved on the hardware GPU,
  while the other half is reserved via host RAM.

if however video memory is not available on hardware GPU,
the vCenter sets the video memory on host RAM

The vCenter does not provide any API which returns
the free video memory on the hardware GPU.
Hence when a instance requires video memory,
the scheduler calculation for a valid host can happen
on the free host memory since vCenter by default uses
host memory if video memory on hardware GPU is not available.

This patch adds the video memory to the requested RAM
for performing the scheduler calculation.

The filter is generic and can be used by any other hypervisors
which have a similar behaviour

This filter is applied only when the flavor
has a extra spec hw_video:video_ram

Support for video memory for VMWare instances is
in review.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/130988/

Co-Authored-By: K M, Bharath Kumar <bharath.k-m@hp.com>

DocImpact
This filter adds the video RAM  to requested RAM for performing
scheduler calculations. Should be enabled if instances spawned
using VMWare driver need to have video memory for correct
scheduler calculations.

Change-Id: I2c1f54465a87e1e006c327f1c8599d8a5384d337
Implements: blueprint vmware-video-memory-filter-scheduler

commit_message:
Support disable_terminate for instance

With 'disable_terminate' option, we can protect instance from being
accidentally terminated. When instance's disable_terminate is true,
instance does not allow to delete. Now nova api does not support it.

Change-Id: I288d351e27c143f65f10a61931759807a89fa299
Implements: blueprint support-disable-terminate-for-instance

commit_message:
Libvirt: Introduce Storage Pool Utilities

This commit introduces storage pool utilities.  Methods have
been added to the `Host` object to lookup and create storage
pools.  Additionally, the `pool_utils` contains information
about standard pool names, as well as a method for looking
up storage volumes in an existing pool.

Implements bp: use-libvirt-storage-pools

Change-Id: I898ea652d50274cbbfd63a0c09556c64e6ef7018

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-02-06 14:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32:

FYI, libvirt docs:

https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsDisks

The optional io attribute controls specific policies on I/O; qemu guests support "threads" and "native". Since 0.8.8

So libvirt version-wise this looks OK, but documentation isn't great on when this should be used or not.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2015-02-06 14:47:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-02-06 15:05:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 32: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

Let's attach this to blueprint improve-nova-kvm-io-support and work it as a spec for the L release, this needs some more thought because the current global config nature of this is too harsh (global as in this affects all kvm instances booted once it's set regardless of their storage)."}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2015-02-06 16:00:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32:

The configuration option is a per-disk type (block/file/network), I have explained that is the specs and we other approach:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153611/'}, {'account_id': 12909, 'date': '2015-02-09 13:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6984, 'date': '2015-02-16 14:29:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 32: -Code-Review

@Sean: is it something that we really want to expose to users? Let's be honest no one is going to use this option with glance properties unless they operate the platform. What's the benefit for the user to do so? We want this to be global because the operator decided that instances perform better with this option. Having this applied at the hypervisor level is enough since you can have different set of compute (aggregate+AZ) backend by different storage backend.

Operators know their storage backend so they are the only one to decide which option to use.

@Matt and others: I still don't understand why we are blocking such trivial feature, this has no impact on user and it's purely an operator decision to provide better user performance experience.

This option is just like the caching option and its type based (file, network etc), so I don't think this has a huge impact."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2015-02-16 15:17:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 32: Code-Review-1

I agree that this needs some better thought behind it than just exposing a config option to cloud admins. For a start different storage technologies could need different settings, so a per-host level config won't fly if you consider multiple cinder backend drivers need supporting in addition to local image storage. I think this is really a case where Nova should be doing the right setting for the particular storage backend itself rather than expecting admins to figure out what to set this to by trial & error."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-02-26 01:36:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32: Verified-1

commit_message:
libvirt: allows to configure disk driver IO policy

libvirt allows to configure the disk IO policy with io=native or
io=threads

This change allows to configure that in nova, so the XML generated for
libvirt have the io=... option set for disks and volumes
when the configuration option disk_io_policies is set.

Everything is done exactly like the disk_cachemode, per
disk source_type. So the configuration option looks like:

[libvirt]
disk_io_policies = file=threads,network=native

DocImpact: New libvirt.disk_io_policies option added.

Closes-Bug: #1399573
Change-Id: Iaaa298029e139690526a61de51b569dd8d34236d

I'm kinda confused by this.  I had some questions/comments in the Cinder version of this as well (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/92479/).  There's the question of overlap with some of the work being done already and why not just use the FC connector etc.

The bigger concern here is I'm not sure how you keep consistency here?  I suppose you could just try and rely on Nova not attaching the same LV to more than one instance at a time but I'm not sure I see how that can be ensured here.  Ideally sure, you'd want to have multi-attach but there needs to be some awareness built in to make that work properly.

It seems like leveraging Walt's work on multi-attach and adding an FC connector for LVM might be a better way to go here.  This implementation seems to just rely on all of the plumbing and connectivity being done by the admin outside of OpenStack and then *used*.  Maybe I'm missing how this goes together."}, {'account_id': 7069, 'date': '2014-05-06 23:36:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck migrations'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-05-07 19:14:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Irrespective of John G's comments about whether this is a tenable solution compared to the other possible solutions, I've left some notes inline on things that should be cleaned up if this moves forward.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 10115, 'date': '2014-05-07 22:41:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi John Griffith-san,

Thank you for your comment. I commented inline.

>>This implementation seems to just rely on all of the plumbing and connectivity being done by 
>>the admin outside of OpenStack and then *used*.

Yes. This is right.
I think this comment is an important point of my suggestion and also the point
is an advantage as well as a weak point.

Currently cinder drivers support limited model of storages, so if we don't have
specific vendor cinder driver(ex. HDS cinder driver), we can not use the storage
for cinder back-end.
But using my suggested cinder driver, cinder will be able to support any kinds
of storages which can export shared volume without a vendor cinder driver because
the my suggested driver uses pre-configured VG. This is an one of benefit.

As for weak point, as you mentioned above, my suggested cinder driver needs
admin preparation of the plumbing and connectivity of storage volume
beforehand.

Could you give me a comment for this point?

>>I'm kinda confused by this. I had some questions/comments in the Cinder version of this as
>>well (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/92479/). There's the question of overlap with some of
>. the work being done already and why not just use the FC connector etc.

Please see comments below.

>>Ideally sure, you'd want to have multi-attach but there needs to be some awareness built in 
>>to make that work properly.

I'm confusing about this comment.
The multi-attach support is not a target of my suggestion.
My suggested driver only attaches a LV to one instance.
This design is same as other cinder drivers.

>>The bigger concern here is I'm not sure how you keep consistency here? I suppose you could
>>just try and rely on Nova not attaching the same LV to more than one instance at a time but
>>I'm not sure I see how that can be ensured here.

Let me confirm a background of this question.

Do you have a concern about a consistency of filesystem on LV(logical volume)?
If the LV attached to multiple instance at the same time and these instances
access to the filesystem(ext4, etc) on the LV, data on the filesystem becomes
inconsistent.(To avoid this thing, we need to use shared filesystem such as NFS)

But as you mentioned above, current Nova implementation does not permit to
attach the same LV to more than one instance. Also my suggested driver only
attaches a LV to one instance.

So I suppose there is no consistency problem.
If I miss to understand your question, please let me know.

>>It seems like leveraging Walt's work on multi-attach and adding an FC connector
>> for LVM might be a better way to go here. 

I may not understand correctly, but what your suggestion is, for example,
Step1 Create a cinder volume from back-end storage and attaches the volume as 
      sharable to multiple computes.
Step2 Create a VG on top of the cinder volume
Step3 Create a LV from the VG(cinder volume on cinder volume)
Step4 Attach a LV to instance using connector(FC?) for LVM

I seems this requires new mechanism for cinder.

Regards,
Mitsuhiro Tanino"}, {'account_id': 10115, 'date': '2014-06-03 20:34:24.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/s to bp/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage'}, {'account_id': 10115, 'date': '2014-06-09 15:12:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-09 15:12:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-05-06 19:26:35.000000000', 'message': 'LVM: Support a volume-gorup on shared storage

Currently LVM driver uses software iSCSI target to export a
volume-group. This patch adds a feature to support a volume-group on
shared storage instead of exporting via iSCSI target. When a
volume-group on a shared storage (over fibre, iscsi or whatever) is
visible from all nodes such as a cinder node and compute nodes, these
nodes can access the volume-group simultaneously without the target.

General benefits
- Enable cinder to any kinds of shared storages without specific cinder
  driver.
- In regard to one storage, use both specific cinder driver and cinder
  shared LVM driver as the situation demands.
- Provide quicker volume and snapshot creation.

*Note that this requires a Cinder lvm SharedLVMDriver as well.
 - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage
 - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage

Change-Id: Ic280e569d963c25f424d5dbc329bcb08fdaba04c
Signed-off-by: Mitsuhiro Tanino <mitsuhiro.tanino@hds.com>
Implements: blueprint lvm-driver-for-shared-storage

'}, {'created': '2014-11-14 00:51:42.000000000', 'message': 'LVM: Support a volume-group on shared storage

This proposal enables LVM driver to support direct data path(I/O path)
from VMs to Storage array using LVM on shared storage instead of using
I/O path which goes through software SCSI target. As a result, the I/O
path can be independent of Cinder Node. By enabling direct I/O path
provides stable I/O path for VMs and improves throughput for VMs.

*Note: In this feature, both Nova and Cinder pieces are necessary.

 Blueprints:
  * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage
  * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage

 Gerrit Review:

  * cinder: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/92479/

commit_message:
LVM: Support a volume-group on shared storage

This proposal enables LVM driver to support direct data path(I/O path)
from VMs to Storage array using LVM on shared storage instead of using
I/O path which goes through software SCSI target. As a result, the I/O
path can be independent of Cinder Node. By enabling direct I/O path
provides stable I/O path for VMs and improves I/O latency.

*Note: In this feature, both Nova and Cinder pieces are necessary.

Change-Id: Ic280e569d963c25f424d5dbc329bcb08fdaba04c
Signed-off-by: Mitsuhiro Tanino <mitsuhiro.tanino@hds.com>
Implements: blueprint lvm-driver-for-shared-storage

commit_message:
Add floating_ips_bulk policy enforcement test case for v2.1 REST API layer

This patch adds floating_ips_bulk policy enforcement unittest for v2.1
REST API layer.

Partially implements bp v3-api-policy

Change-Id: Ib6888b54896235d52390a0e1204b119d8366ad7c

I understand the aim of the patch but i'm not agree with where we are going here...

Why we want to retrieve more than 1000 instances? do we really want to print more than 1000 instances to the user?

To fix this problem we need to use database cursor and real pagination. We do never want to retrieve more than 1000 instances."}, {'account_id': 8276, 'date': '2015-02-28 03:11:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi @sahid:

The core problem is rpc timeout of init_host() and _sync_power_states() when calling InstanceList.get_by_host in the case of nova with VMWare driver. One nova-compute maybe hold the thousands of VMWare instances because one nova-compute contact several VMWare clusters, it don't have relation to print instances to user, just fix the rpc timeout between nova-compute and nova-conductor when init_host() and _sync_power_states()."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2015-02-28 08:36:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Yes i have understand the aim of you patch. I just think that your solution is not viable. The is a timeout because we try to get too many instances and we store all of references in a map. It works for other drivers since usually a compute host about 50 instances. Also If we continue like that to store the references of thousand and thousand instances in the map we will get an out of memory on the compute node. I mean this does not work and we need to think about a real pattern to fix this issue not something like looks a hack.'}, {'account_id': 8276, 'date': '2015-03-02 02:52:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

yep, we only face the issue in VMWare driver. currently in nova,  there are unified compute manager and object model, but the unified InstanceList object will handle different use case for different hypervisor (VMWare and others). Yes, I know that we must improve the nova architecture in order to fix the problem, but maybe it need long term plan. 

The patch as short term fix.'}, {'account_id': 8276, 'date': '2015-03-03 09:12:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-03 10:28:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

IMO, I am afraid I don't agree with sahid about the this patch. 

Take vSphere 6.0 into consideration, there will be a maximum of 6000 vms per Cluster(the number was 4000 with vSphere 5.5), corresponding to 1 nova-compute process. nova-conductor will spend more time to retrieve so many vms information, which will casue rpc timeout for nova-compute. I agree that db cursor and something like pagination machanism would resolve the problem for nova-conductor. However, it rally make little sense for nova-compute(rpc timeout), unless we could take really good care of the corresponding relationship between rpc communication and the 'pagination mechanism'. 

Anyway, it seems we still need more than one rpc calling, which Rui is proposing in this patch. We can wait to see other core reviewers' opinion, or we can bring this to the maillist for more feedback."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-12 22:52:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified-1

Please check of failed test.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-03-23 16:56:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

I really don't think this is a bug. This is an architectural concern with using a single nova-compute to manage a large hypervisor cluster with thousands of instances. That runs very contrary to the design and implementation of nova, which is why you're having timeouts.

I think this patch specifically doesn't do full pagination, but also that we shouldn't have to do that based on the current design. Thus, I think all this does is introduce a bug of artificially limiting the results of the affected call and potentially causing lots of other issues in that case."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-03-23 16:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)

Forgot to commit a couple comments.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-03-23 17:38:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

So, this patch actually does do the pagination (see comment inline). However, I agree with Dan and Sahid that the reason you are running into this bug (which isn't really a bug, IMO) is due to the vCenter virt driver's clustered architecture not "jiving" with the architecture of nova-compute, which is to only manage the small set of resources on an individual bare metal node.

That said, the vCenter driver isn't alone in this problem. The Ironic driver suffers from the same architectural mismatch, as does the Docker driver, IIRC.

We need a real solution, not one that just pretends the architecture/assumptions of the underlying resource manager don't cause any conflicts :)

-jay'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2015-03-23 18:28:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

You're right about this specific version of the code, but in general it can't implement pagination because the remotable_classmethods have to remain as such. That means we batch the conversation with the DB, but then send the entire result over RPC when we're done. We'd have to change every _caller_ to use a new and different interface.

But anyway, yeah as I said, I don't think the actual problem is this call anyway :)"}, {'account_id': 8276, 'date': '2015-03-25 12:17:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Thanks for @Jay and @Dan's comments.

If I'm wrong, please correct me.

The vCenter driver is a part of nova, but looks like that its implementation actually mismatch with the architecture of nova-compute. 

Whether there is any plan for solving this type issue?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-03-25 13:13:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Hi Rui,

Yeah, you are correct that this has been an issue for quite some time now, with no proper solution.

We need to settle a long-term plan at the design summit. I will ensure that we have a long design session and a proposal with a way forward.

Are you planning to attend in Vancouver?

-jay'}, {'account_id': 8276, 'date': '2015-03-25 13:39:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Yes, I'm planning to attend in Vancouver, maybe we can discuss this issue face to face in design summit.

Best Regards."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-05-13 17:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This review is > 4 weeks without comment and currently blocked by a core reviewer with a -2. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and contacting the reviewer with the -2 on this review to ensure you address their concerns.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-05-13 17:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

This review is > 4 weeks without comment and currently blocked by a core reviewer with a -2. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and contacting the reviewer with the -2 on this review to ensure you address their concerns.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-02-13 08:33:29.000000000', 'message': 'VMware: fix InstanceList.get_by_host rpc timeout

The method of InstanceList.get_by_host rasie rpc timeout error when
ComputeManager.init_host() and _sync_power_states periodic task execute.

Currently, one nova-compute host map to the whole VMware deployment that
maybe contain several clusters in nova VMware driver. When
InstanceList.get_by_host execute in ComputeManager, it indicate that
nova-compute will execute a rpc call to nova-conducutor, nova-conductor
will fetch a lots of instances in the whole VMware deployment in once,
The long time SQL query maybe lead to the nova-conductor rpc timeout.

Paginate query for InstanceList.get_by_host and
InstanceList.get_by_host_and_node. The default page size is 1000.

Change-Id: Ic768fe74583e77ac1dc1ef725e8787b009bb5234
Closes-Bug: #1420662
'}, {'created': '2015-02-16 08:37:47.000000000', 'message': 'VMware: fix InstanceList.get_by_host rpc timeout

Change-Id: Ic768fe74583e77ac1dc1ef725e8787b009bb5234
Closes-Bug: #1420662
'}]
commit_message:
Fix InstanceList.get_by_host rpc timeout

The method of InstanceList.get_by_host raise rpc timeout error when
ComputeManager.init_host() and _sync_power_states periodic task execute.

Currently, one nova-compute host map to the whole VMware deployment that
maybe contain several clusters in nova VMware driver. When
InstanceList.get_by_host execute in ComputeManager, it indicate that
nova-compute will execute a rpc call to nova-conductor, nova-conductor
will fetch a lots of instances in the whole VMware deployment in once,
The long time SQL query maybe lead to the nova-conductor rpc timeout.

Paginate query for InstanceList.get_by_host and
InstanceList.get_by_host_and_node. The default page size is 1000.

Change-Id: Ic768fe74583e77ac1dc1ef725e8787b009bb5234
Closes-Bug: #1420662

I don't think we want to do this in the general case. This has the potential to generate a lot of noise on the message bus, especially for drivers that don't care that display_name has changed. For things that we need to notify the compute node about, we can and should make a call, but doing it in the general case is not a good idea IMHO."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2015-03-27 16:17:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Dan I am not sure what noise there will be - this is one message sent when a user updates something on the instance. At the moment the libvirt driver has metadata that is related to the properties of the instance. So you want that data to be out of sync? My understand is that it was very helpful for admins.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-03-30 18:34:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified-1

commit_message:
Ensure that API updates notify compute node

The nova API enables the user to update an instance. This information
is not passed to the hypervisor so that it can update instance
properties (if necessary).

An example of this is the meta data stored by libvirt.

Change-Id: I3ccda5586511620149833f31fc28d4d07196e582
Partial-bug: #1430807

commit_message:
support getting quota usage for all tenants

For performance reasons, it's preferable to get
quota info for tenants in a single request,
rather than iterating over all tenants.

Similarly to the /v2/{tenant_id}/servers/detail API
which supports an "all_tenants" parameter to return the list,
support /v2/{tenant_id}/limits/detail?all_tenants=True

Closes-Bug: #1410003
Change-Id: Ie642c3fab9755986ec2a956efe1d3cd7f85d345d
Implements: blueprint nova-quota-admin-api

commit_message:
Copy instance files from source to dest node

In case instance_path is not configured on shared storage between compute
nodes, then there is a need to copy instance files from the shelved_host
to the newly elected compute node during unshelving instance.

Added new interface 'copy_instance_files_to_destination' in virt driver
and implemented in libvirt driver for copying the instance files from
source to destination host. For other drivers, this method will
raise NotImplementedError. Service providers should configure
shelve_offload_time parameter to -2 only when they are using libvirt
driver.

Change-Id: If642c0b5d44acbf353af6b6e901b40e345843555
blueprint: improve-unshelve-performance

commit_message:
Bring Redhat support to acceptance tests

OpenStack Infra has jobs to run this on both Ubuntu Trusty and CentOS7.

* Add minitest to Gemfile (dependency to run beaker on centos - see
  http://projects.theforeman.org/issues/2650 for details)
* separate nodepool files to have trusty & centos7 support in OS infra
* basic_keystone_spec: add case for repo configuration and support
  RH systems.
* rabbitmq: install module from source and on RH, install erlang before rabbitmq-server.

Change-Id: Ie6c823c7906afb37dd9e49fa434fefc3e26b5569
Closes-bug: #1444736

Beaker: install APT repo with openstack_extras

Use openstack_extras module to manage Ubuntu Cloud Archive repository.

Change-Id: I5bf3bd0e2e1b8db49752abca823203ff225713c4

commit_message:
Bring Redhat support to acceptance tests

OpenStack Infra has jobs to run this on both Ubuntu Trusty and CentOS7.

* Add minitest to Gemfile (dependency to run beaker on centos - see
  http://projects.theforeman.org/issues/2650 for details)
* separate nodepool files to have trusty & centos7 support in OS infra
* basic_keystone_spec: add case for repo configuration and support
  RH systems.

Change-Id: Ia2e91512c097c3aa1cff9bf7f868ae08f86a44df
Closes-bug: #1444736

commit_message:
Add new HostAggregateGroupFilter scheduler filter

Added new scheduler filter 'HostAggregateGroupFilter' which can filter
hosts on the basis of 'host_aggregate_group_id' passed to the
filter_properties parameter for scheduling new instances.

DocImpact:
If HostAggregate groups configured with same properties on multiple NFS,
then add 'HostAggregateGroupFilter' in the 'scheduler_default_filters'
configuration parameter as mentioned below:
scheduler_default_filters=HostAggregateGroupFilter,AvailabilityZoneFilter,...

Change-Id: I67f2dd372968740a21f70cd04bc4adc996020942
blueprint: improve-unshelve-performance

commit_message:
Avoids Error code 500 on negative port quota

Currently if the quota_port value in the neutron.conf is set to a
negative value not equal to -1, the nova boot command fails.
The negative number should ideally signify a unlimited port quota.

The fix allows the flexibility of having any negative number for the
quota_port parameter in the neutron.conf file and allows the nova boot
to succeed subsequently.

Change-Id: I5af5af1009b2f491d259fbe024d2f7f36ba5c4b2
Closes-Bug: 1438738

Thanks for investigating.

libvirt 1.2.9 has had no. of block layer fixes, and  I've not managed to reproduce the bug # 1334398 in my local tests with libvirt 1.2.11 and QEMU 2.2.0."}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2015-01-15 11:45:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It'd be highly useful if we can manage to GDB to the hung QEMU process (supply -S option to QEMU) to investigate the root cause. Just to recap, the below is where it's stuck last Dan Berrange captured from his debugging[1]

[. . .]
: Send command '{"execute":"query-block-
jobs","id":"libvirt-15"}' for write with FD -1

This clearly shows that at 11:05:50, libvirtd sends a request to QEMU 'query-block-jobs'. Approx three minutes libvirtd gets a 'virDomainDestroy' request from Nova, at which point we get the virDomainBlockAbort error due to death of QEMU.
. . .
In the time where libvirtd is waiting for the QEMU response, there are many other libvirt API calls taking place, so it doesn't look like libvirtd itself is misbehaving. It also successfully sees the EOF on the QEMU monitor socket, so we can see the event loop is still listening for the reply from QEMU.
[. . .]

Also, there's an in-progress patch[2] that enables you to build libvirt/QEMU from source which can probably aid in debugging here.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1334398/comments/27
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/108714/ -- Support for libvirt/QEMU tar releases'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2015-01-15 16:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: enable libvirt live snapshot (testing)

Checking to see if this fails on the fedora 21 experimental
queue job with libvirt 1.2.9 and qemu 2.1.2. The goal is to
try and find a more reasonable minimum version cap for this
feature.

Related-Bug: #1334398

Change-Id: I3c27b6d37f04580b280c75940fe172fe7255ba51

commit_message:
Share common RST directory

Move the user-guides common directory up and share it with the
networking guide as well. For this, we need to use relative links of the
directory so that the directory is inside the tree.

For networking-guide, blacklist unused common files using the
exclude_pattern.

Change-Id: I1301effd64b676f2ee0aa43543df85f423e79e0a

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I9d3e80d94795060d375aae30ce249513aae3fd97

commit_message:
ISCSI be careful parsing iscsiadm output

Sometimes iscsiadm can output debugging text.
This patch does the same thing that the old
nova libvirt volume code does in being safe
with reading the command line output.  We want
to ensure that we are reading the iqns and ips.

Change-Id: I092a56e52bcea6adb6cb018cd059e6126a1dc07d
Closes-Bug: #1453992

Lots of good effort here. I haven't been following the pacemaker stuff that closely but actually seeing it now I think it is clear to me that the $enable_pacemaker conditionals make our overcloud template quite a conditional mess. Understood that I sort of asked for this "feature" in that I would like the ability to run without pacemaker...

So, an idea. What if instead of all these $enable_pacemaker conditionals we duplicate the entire overcloud_controller manifest. Perhaps this means we move some (as little as possible) stuff to puppet-tripleo... like maybe the DB creation resources. Yes, there would be some duplication but there already is quite a bit with the pacemaker logic anyways.

I really just don't like how this is turning out from a readability/maintenance prospective. If we just remove all the pacemaker conditionals (and have 2 manifests) then I think it might be more reasonable.'}, {'account_id': 7984, 'date': '2015-05-07 13:30:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

@dprince - I would agree with the idea of layering the pacemaker confiugration.  We did something similar in quickstack, having all our quickstack::pacemaker classes just call the quickstack::<service> classes, allowing the same classes to be (in theory) used with or without pacemaker'}, {'account_id': 7984, 'date': '2015-05-07 18:20:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

roller-xdhz6wypdk5n ]


Clustercheck also looks good:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Connection: close

Galera cluster node is synced.


Databases are also created:

MariaDB [(none)]> show databases;
+--------------------+
| Database           |
+--------------------+
| cinder             |
| glance             |
| heat               |
| information_schema |
| keystone           |
| mysql              |
| nova               |
| ovs_neutron        |
| performance_schema |
| test               |
+--------------------+


However, none of the databases have any tables.  Is there some manual setting I missed?  It looks like whatever node evaluates to true for pacemaker_master should set sync_db to true, and this node would be determined by:
./overcloud-without-mergepy.yaml:      bootstrap_nodeid: {get_attr: [Controller, resource.0.hostname]}

Am I missing something?'}, {'account_id': 9410, 'date': '2015-05-11 10:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-11 10:25:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-27 13:30:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add Galera support with Pacemaker

This commit aims to support the creation of the galera cluster via
Pacemaker. With this commit in, three use-cases will be supported.

 * Non HA setup / Non Pacemaker setup : The deployment will take place
as it is currently the case in f20puppet-nonha. Nothing changes.

 * Non HA setup / Pacemaker setup : Even though it is a non ha setup,
galera cluster via pacemaker  will be deployed with a cluster nbr of 1.

 * HA setup / Non Pacemaker setup : N/A

 * HA setup / Pacemaker setup : It is assumed that HA setup will
always be with pacemaker.  So in this situation pacemaker will deploy a
cluster of 3 galera master nodes.

commit_message:
Add Galera as a Pacemaker resource when EnablePacemaker

This commit aims to support the creation of the galera cluster via
Pacemaker. With this commit in, three use-cases will be supported.

 * Non HA setup / Non Pacemaker setup : The deployment will take place
as it is currently the case in f20puppet-nonha. Nothing changes.

 * Non HA setup / Pacemaker setup : Even though it is a non ha setup,
galera cluster via pacemaker  will be deployed with a cluster nbr of 1.

 * HA setup / Non Pacemaker setup : N/A

 * HA setup / Pacemaker setup : It is assumed that HA setup will
always be with pacemaker.  So in this situation pacemaker will deploy a
cluster of 3 galera master nodes.

Depends-On: I7aed9acec11486e0f4f67e4d522727476c767d83
Change-Id: If0c37a86fa8b5aa6d452129bccf7341a3a3ba667

commit_message:
Fix path issue to controller-config-pacemaker

Currently the CI is failing with: Could not fetch contents for
file:///opt/stack/new/puppet/controller-config-pacemaker.yaml; when
running heat stack-create. Fixing the path of the overcloud-ha.yaml
file to fix this.

Change-Id: I7aed9acec11486e0f4f67e4d522727476c767d83

patchset 12 is now based on the list change to work with query parameters, but that's about the only difference. I'm wondering now if this should remain explicit in either trying by name or ID, or if it should try by ID first and as a backup try by name regardless. An alternative I thought of is having by_name be set to None, rather than True or False, so it may implicitly try both ID and name, unless you set it to either True or False...or something that would allow different control of how it's tried.

Now between the list change and this get change, we enable finer filtering of listed resources and the ability to use that filtering to search for matches when trying to get a single resource."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-28 17:57:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-13 21:28:43.000000000', 'message': "Proxy get method

This change introduces a common get API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around getting a single resource. This
change applies the API only to the retrieval of one server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls get on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id.

Since this temporarily involves two separate proxy get APIs, I've
called the test verify_get2. When we apply it everywhere in a mass
change, we will go back to one test.

Note that as this API operates on only a resource or an ID, it works the
same way the delete API does in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/164310/

Change-Id: I2651d7e01b0067865d623dcda3b9b0f6bd43101b
"}, {'created': '2015-03-19 19:19:53.000000000', 'message': "Proxy get method

This change introduces a common get API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around get a single resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to getting a single server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls get on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. Additionally, a decorator has been added that
checks if resources that are passed to it are of the appropriate type
for that operation. For example, this will raise ValueError if you try
to call get_server with a flavor, rather than making the call to the
flavor's ID and having a potentially misleading ResourceNotFound
exception.

Additionally, in conjunction with the by_name parameter, we can try to
return *the* resource with that name. This works by using that
resource's list method, e.g., the currently named list_servers, with
query arguments to narrow down the results to hopefully one value. If
no resources match that name, ResourceNotFound is raised. If more
than one resource matches that name, DuplicateResource is raised. If
caller are expecting multiple resources, they should use the appropriate
list call, e.g., list_servers.

Because a get by_name=True search through the list resource returns
a generator, we need to consume that generator to get the potential
single resource out to be returned, or raise as appropriate.
BaseProxy._get_unique_resource was added to handle this. Because of the
differences in what list calls accept, along with some of the list calls
having detailed and plain resources, e.g., Server and ServerDetail, we
do have to have some minimal logic in the proxy that can't be in the
base. This method contains as much as is generically applicable to solve
the problem.

Note: a combination of this change plus expanded coverage of query
argument support in the list calls, which will be handled as part of
unifying the list APIs, removes the need for Resource.find.

Note 2: as with the delete change, there is a temporary verify_get2 test
method here to work with this API, which will become the one verify
after applying this everywhere.

Change-Id: I2651d7e01b0067865d623dcda3b9b0f6bd43101b
"}, {'created': '2015-03-24 15:32:30.000000000', 'message': "Proxy get method

This change introduces a common get API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around get a single resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to getting a single server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls get on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. The ID is passed to the _check_resource
decorator so we're only making the get call on the appropriate type of
resource, if given. When given a string ID, we have to try it.

Additionally, in conjunction with the by_name parameter, we can try to
return *the* resource with that name. This works by using that
resource's list method, e.g., the currently named list_servers, with
query arguments to narrow down the results to hopefully one value. If
no resources match that name, ResourceNotFound is raised. If more
than one resource matches that name, DuplicateResource is raised. If
caller are expecting multiple resources, they should use the appropriate
list call, e.g., list_servers.

Because a get by_name=True search through the list resource returns
a generator, we need to consume that generator to get the potential
single resource out to be returned, or raise as appropriate.
BaseProxy._get_unique_resource was added to handle this. Because of the
differences in what list calls accept, along with some of the list calls
having detailed and plain resources, e.g., Server and ServerDetail, we
do have to have some minimal logic in the proxy that can't be in the
base. This method contains as much as is generically applicable to solve
the problem.

Note: a combination of this change plus expanded coverage of query
argument support in the list calls, which will be handled as part of
unifying the list APIs, removes the need for Resource.find.

Note 2: as with the delete change, there is a temporary verify_get2 test
method here to work with this API, which will become the one verify
after applying this everywhere.

Change-Id: I2651d7e01b0067865d623dcda3b9b0f6bd43101b
"}, {'created': '2015-03-26 19:27:41.000000000', 'message': "Proxy get method

having detailed and plain resources, e.g., Server and ServerDetail, we
do have to have some minimal logic in the proxy that can't be in the
base. This method contains as much as is generically applicable to solve
the problem.

Note: a combination of this change plus expanded coverage of query
argument support in the list calls, which will be handled as part of
unifying the list APIs, removes the need for Resource.find.

Note 2: as with the delete change, there is a temporary verify_get2 test
method here to work with this API, which will become the one verify
after applying this everywhere.

Change-Id: I2651d7e01b0067865d623dcda3b9b0f6bd43101b
"}, {'created': '2015-03-26 19:43:51.000000000', 'message': "Proxy get method

This change introduces a common get API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around get a single resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to getting a single server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls get on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. The ID is passed to the _check_resource
decorator so we're only making the get call on the appropriate type of
resource, if given. When given a string ID, we have to try it.

Additionally, in conjunction with the by_name parameter, we can try to
return *the* resource with that name. This works by using that
resource's list method, e.g., the currently named list_servers, with
query arguments to narrow down the results to hopefully one value. If
no resources match that name, ResourceNotFound is raised. If more
than one resource matches that name, DuplicateResource is raised. If
caller are expecting multiple resources, they should use the appropriate
list call, e.g., list_servers.

Because a get by_name=True search through the list resource returns
a generator, we need to consume that generator to get the potential
single resource out to be returned, or raise as appropriate.
BaseProxy._get_unique_resource was added to handle this. Because of the
differences in what list calls accept, along with some of the list calls
having detailed and plain resources, e.g., Server and ServerDetail, we
do have to have some minimal logic in the proxy that can't be in the
base. This method contains as much as is generically applicable to solve
the problem.

Note: a combination of this change plus expanded coverage of query
argument support in the list calls, which will be handled as part of
unifying the list APIs, removes the need for Resource.find.

Note 2: as with the delete change, there is a temporary verify_get2 test
method here to work with this API, which will become the one verify
after applying this everywhere.

Change-Id: I2651d7e01b0067865d623dcda3b9b0f6bd43101b

commit_message:
Proxy get method

This change introduces a common get API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around get a single resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to getting a single server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls `get` on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. The ID is passed to the _check_resource
decorator so we're only making the get call on the appropriate type of
resource, if given. When given a string ID, we have to try it.

Change-Id: I2651d7e01b0067865d623dcda3b9b0f6bd43101b

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-12 22:49:27.000000000', 'message': "Don't error on missing certs when not https

If we're not using https, don't throw errors if cert files don't exist.

Change-Id: Iba1a87fee10ba5e5f6d7ea1e70632c47fd67275c
"}, {'created': '2015-05-12 22:55:32.000000000', 'message': "Don't error on missing certs

We were trying to be too helpful. The underlying libraries do the right
thing here.

Change-Id: Iba1a87fee10ba5e5f6d7ea1e70632c47fd67275c
"}]
commit_message:
Don't error on missing certs

We were trying to be too helpful. The underlying libraries do the right
thing here.

Change-Id: Iba1a87fee10ba5e5f6d7ea1e70632c47fd67275c

commit_message:
Remove fallback from get_service_vales

Once os_client_config release 0.8.3, we can remove the fallback and
depend on 0.8.3.

Change-Id: I1b452509c3c755ad8c5bb9dff30c54d01dd16205

commit_message:
Use appdirs for platform-independent locations

Cache, data and config files live rooted in different places across
different OS's. Use appdirs to find where.

Depends-On: Ic939dea11b7476ec504d2bf65854a0781b1bfb39
Change-Id: I7338ae1d0442e0c5cc1ec4ae4d619fac319a4a28

commit_message:
glance: remove deprecated store options

glance_store has now been fully migrated, so we can remove these from the
config files.

Change-Id: I987ab6338b235f0beeed7c7fe74b0f5b6526f70d

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-11 20:11:20.000000000', 'message': "Add appdirs requirement

What?
- appdirs provides platform independent knowledge of appropriate
  directories to use for applications. For instance, instead of
  put in an env reference to XDG_ variables, you can use appdirs and get
  not only the XDG_ dirs on linux, but the analogs on OSX and Windows.

Usage?
- os-client-config
- python-ironicclient

Is the library actively maintained?
- Last modified Aug 2014. The company ActiveState is behind it.

Is the library good code?
- It's neither the best nor worst code I've seen. Its documented well.

Is the library python 3 compatible?
- Yes

Is the library license compatible?
- Yes, MIT licensed

Is the library already packaged in the distros we target?
- https://packages.debian.org/sid/python-appdirs
- https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/python-appdirs
- Does *not* currently seem to exist in fedora

Is the function of this library already covered by other
libraries in ``global-requirements.txt``?
- No

Change-Id: Ic939dea11b7476ec504d2bf65854a0781b1bfb39
"}]
commit_message:
Add appdirs requirement

What?
- appdirs provides platform independent knowledge of appropriate
  directories to use for applications. For instance, instead of
  put in an env reference to XDG_ variables, you can use appdirs and get
  not only the XDG_ dirs on linux, but the analogs on OSX and Windows.

Usage?
- os-client-config
- python-ironicclient

Is the library actively maintained?
- Last modified Aug 2014. The company ActiveState is behind it.

Is the library good code?
- It's neither the best nor worst code I've seen. Its documented well.

Is the library python 3 compatible?
- Yes

Is the library license compatible?
- Yes, MIT licensed

Is the library already packaged in the distros we target?
- https://packages.debian.org/sid/python-appdirs
- https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/python-appdirs
- Does *not* currently seem to exist in fedora

Is the function of this library already covered by other
libraries in ``global-requirements.txt``?
- No

Change-Id: Ic939dea11b7476ec504d2bf65854a0781b1bfb39

commit_message:
Fix raise syntax in test.py for python3 compat

The raise syntax was changed in python3 so the usage of passing in
the separate components as different params to raise will not work
when running on python 3. This commit updates it to use a syntax
which is compatible with python3.

Change-Id: I5cb9979e8ba8e324efb95feec33c23238dffade5

(4 comments)

I'm having extreme difficultly following your analysis - which is almost certainly due to my lack of recent face-time with the update code more than any failing on your part - but if you could post some details about exactly which versions of the resources are getting stored where and how this solves the problem, that would be helpful.

I'm pretty strongly opposed to elements of this patch, but I think some of the work you've done on tracking this down, if not the code itself, could be salvageable - see inline comments.

My fear is that you may have hit a (known) bug that is unfixable in the current architecture. If you look at bug 1270775 (check out the attached diagram by the way, it's really helpful)... there is a related bug that occurs on update (rather than delete, which was fixed in that bug). And there is no way to solve that in general without having infinite levels of backup stacks. As long as there is only one backup stack, we can't do the Right Thing in the general case - which is that the failed resource has not necessarily just been created, and may in fact have real physical resources depending on it. It's possible that you may be able to hack in a fix for your particular failure mode without breaking any of the stuff that works already, but it could easily prove very difficult to do.

The convergence architecture that we hope to move to in Liberty will solve this problem by getting rid of the backup stack and giving each resource its own memory of its dependencies. (Not to mention handling creates and deletes using the same code as updates.)"}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2015-05-05 12:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2015-05-05 12:32:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Zane, 
I prepared the more secure solution.
The root cause of the problem is related to dependencies: if we are trying to build dependencies then we will face with invalid references in backup stack. So the patch solves this problem in straight way: we just simply ignore these errors when we are building backup stack. It seems less risky and applicable for murano case.
Looking forward for your opinion.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2015-05-05 14:26:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

This definitely looks less risky, so I'm dropping the -2. One possible issue mentioned inline.

We did discuss another possible plan of attack on IRC. I think the issue here could be that when we do an update that adds a new resource to the template, it doesn't get added to the template of the backup stack. So in update.py near the bottom of StackUpdate._create_resource() (before we add the resource to the current stack) we could try checking whether the resource to be created exists in the previous stack and, if not, adding it to the previous stack's template.

It may be that we also need to update the template of the backup stack whenever we update a resource in place and there is no backup resource (i.e. the state is INIT_COMPLETE), to keep the dependencies up to date.

It would be interesting to try out this approach and see if it also solves the problem, because it seems to me that it could be a bit cleaner."}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2015-05-05 16:33:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2015-05-05 16:37:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Zane,
I changed the place where we need to check presence of resources in backup stack. it seems that it is too early to save resources to backup before creating because if resource create will fail we will get incorrect backup stack. So I propose to check resource when we are trying to update resources in-place. In this case the resource that need to be saved to backup have to be correct.'}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2015-05-05 19:13:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-05 20:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified-1

- check-tripleo-ironic-overcloud-precise-nonha http://logs.openstack.org/68/175868/11/check-tripleo/check-tripleo-ironic-overcloud-precise-nonha/72d3382/ : SUCCESS in 1h 14m 52s'}, {'account_id': 7227, 'date': '2015-05-07 12:51:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 13323, 'date': '2015-05-08 13:50:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2015-05-08 20:00:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

I'm hovering between -1 and +2 on this, so I'm setting +1 but it would be great if we could clear up a couple of questions so I can be sure. This change is definitely necessary and the patch looks great, I just want to be sure it's also sufficient.

> it seems that it is too early to save resources to backup before creating because if resource create will fail we will get incorrect backup stack.

Can you elaborate on why this is incorrect? We're not storing a resource for the backup stack, only updating the template, so it's not like there'll be a failed resource stored in the backup stack. And the failed resource really will exist in the main stack, so why is it wrong for it to appear in the backup's template?

> So I propose to check resource when we are trying to update resources in-place. In this case the resource that need to be saved to backup have to be correct.

My only concern with this approach is that it might not work in some scenarios that are different to the particular one you are testing. The problem you're solving here is that the backup template is supposed to mirror the actual template, and it does when it's first created, but if a backup stack already exists when starting an update then the current template doesn't get copied over. The proposed solution leaves the templates out of sync at the point where a new resource has been created during the most recent stack update. I _think_ we get away with this anomaly in the case of deleting the stack because of the fix for bug 1270775; and in the update case because it takes a second update to produce a second failed resource that causes the first to need deletion from the backup stack, and the second update also updates the port in place and brings the templates back into agreement.

So to sum up, we definitely need this change (because it's not enough to just have the resource in the backup template - it needs to be up to date otherwise it could have broken deps). We can make a hand-wavy argument that it's probably sufficient. It would be a bit easier to reason about if the template were always in sync, so I'd prefer to do it on create too unless there is a legitimate reason not to (i.e. it breaks something)."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2015-05-11 03:44:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-11 03:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: -Verified

- gate-tempest-dsvm-heat http://logs.openstack.org/68/175868/11/gate/gate-tempest-dsvm-heat/cd59427/ : SUCCESS in 18m 11s'}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2015-05-13 08:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Zane, thanks for review and sorry for late response.
Let me explain the main reason why I do not put resources to backup when the new resources are creating during update:
If I understand correctly the whole idea of backup stack the main goal is store somewhere stack definition BEFORE update. So we can rollback to the previous definition without any troubles. If we put some resource to backup stack before resource creation then it is not quite cleat how to restore the previous definition of the stack (if something will be wrong). Otherwise, it is quite strange for me as a typical user why do we need these backups.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2015-05-13 15:21:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

The backup stack is a holding place for resources that have been replaced during an update, while they still have other resources depending on them. If we have to roll back during the update then we try to re-insert the original resource rather than create a second replacement. We never restore the backup stack wholesale, we only pick resources out of it. In this case since the resource appears only in the template and not in the database, it will always be in the state INIT_COMPLETE and thus never considered for being restored to the main stack.

The template we restore in the event of a rollback isn't the one from the backup stack, it's one we clone from the current stack before starting the update: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/heat/tree/heat/engine/stack.py?h=stable%2Fkilo#n905 (oldstack in Stack.update_task())

The whole existence of a backup stack is a giant hack and I completely understand your confusion :)

That said, nothing I'm hearing suggests to me that inserting the resource definition into the backup template just before the resource is created would be a problem, and I'd still prefer that we do that as well.

I wonder if we also need to remove the resource from the backup template again in StackUpdate._remove_backup_resource()."}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:03:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Zane, thanks a lot for comments again. Now, I understand the reasons why it was made in such way:). 
I can provide at least one example when your proposal can break something:
Let's pretend the following scenario:
s1) successful stack-create
s2) update of stack from s1 where we introduce some new resource. The update is failed but resource was created successfully. According to your approach, we should backup this resource. 
s3) we replacing the resource from s2) with another stack-update. It also can be failed. According to current realization this resource will be stored to backup stack. 
After that, we have two similar resources in backup stack and i am not sure that heat can treat such cases correctly.
Could you please provide your opinion about this?"}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:04:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I can prepare more illustration if you need but I need some time to prepare it. So please ping me if you need additional clarification)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2015-05-13 16:27:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

(For those following along at home, we discussed this on IRC and agreed it wasn't a problem.)"}]

The patch prohibit backup for failed resources during stack-update.
If a resource update/create or smth else has been failed
we should not backup and save the resource to DB. Otherwise, we will
face with InvalidTemplateReference if update has been failed again
and the resource has a reference to some resources from the updated
stack. The error will raise during deletion of backup stack.

The patch defines a property that generates dependencies for
backup stack in special way: it ignores all references to resources
that does not exist in the stack and try to build dependencies
for all other resources.
Without this functionality, InvalidTemplateReference will be thrown
every time when update-replaced resource has a reference to updated
in-place resource and stack update was failed. In this case, backup
stack has a resource that refers to not-presented another resource
and backup stack deletion generates an exception.

commit_message:
Save updated-in-place resources to backup stack

The patch changes the approach of resource backup during stack
update. It stores the definition of resource that needs to be
updated in-place to backup stack(if it was not created before).

Without this functionality, InvalidTemplateReference will be thrown
every time when update-replaced resource has a reference to updated
in-place resource and stack update was failed. In this case, backup
stack has a resource that refers to not-presented another resource
and backup stack deletion generates an exception.

Change-Id: I436c44a579bb4df3031d1a17b9ca5b62da37afeb
Closes-bug: #1446575
