revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-08 22:43:52.000000000', 'message': 'Dell: Added support for update_migrated_volume

Added support for updated_migrated_volume to common driver.
Added rename_volume to dell_storagecenter_api to support it.
Added tests to test_dellsc.py and test_dellapi.py.

The only thing we do in this rename the newly migrated volume
destination volume on the Dell Storage center to be the same
as the original volume ID.  Since we identify the volumes
by volume ID this prevents them from being lost.

Change-Id: I531e24853cf5db8b7c34d91460d3abe786a652de
Closes-bug: 1452919
(cherry picked from commit fc09713f2c8102d4b04c8df57fc401a34525d79e)
'}]
commit_message:
Dell: Added support for update_migrated_volume

Added support for updated_migrated_volume to common driver.
Added rename_volume to dell_storagecenter_api to support it.
Added tests to test_dellsc.py and test_dellapi.py.

The only thing we do in this rename the newly migrated volume
destination volume on the Dell Storage center to be the same
as the original volume ID.  Since we identify the volumes
by volume ID this prevents them from being lost.

Change-Id: I531e24853cf5db8b7c34d91460d3abe786a652de
Closes-bug: 1452919
(cherry picked from commit fc09713f2c8102d4b04c8df57fc401a34525d79e)

commit_message:
Don't wait for an event on a resize-revert

Since we never unplugged, the event ain't comin'.

Sadly, the test that covers this was pretty wrong on multiple fronts,
which this patch fixes up.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py
	nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py

Closes-Bug: #1450624
Change-Id: Id515137747a4b76e9b7057c95f80c8ae74017519
(cherry picked from commit 4814e9126ec19a1edfa9c696138c4b3fec71aa0d)

commit_message:
Add consts for scaling adjustment types

This patch moves the const string definition of scaling adjustment types
to the shared consts module. It will be used by standalone scaling
policies and the RESIZE operations.

Change-Id: I1f7402e5d4c40e580d6f247023cc3b66c7f10d94

Add deploy environment murano benchmark

* deploy-environment benchmark. Used to upload
  specified package and deploy it in environment.

Change-Id: I8312527ee4a6aa164a9545e52c8bd5f0381ebeb8
Co-Authored-By: Roman Vasilets <rvasilets@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Sergey Murashov <smurashov@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Fix several small nits in network v2 proxy

Just fix some clerical errors in comments of network v2
_proxy module.

Change-Id: Ifcb54739c886aa0277df515c1b184789a0253500

commit_message:
Removes temporary fix for doc generation

A temporary fix was added to get around a bug in how pbr handles
its autodoc_tree_index_modules setting. Since this bug is fixed we no
longer need the work around.

Change-Id: Id8274ef5c244bf50a34702ed9b4e50d3b82d8028
Closes-Bug: #1260495

commit_message:
Split runners to base and plugins

Move all subclasses of runners under plugins/runners

Implements: blueprint split-plugins
Change-Id: I67edb7f09e1e98dcbd20d4d0d5a40351bdedc064

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-12 23:24:54.000000000', 'message': "Don't shallow clone from file:// in integration test

Shallow cloning ends up writing a temporary file in the source git repo,
but we may not have write access to it. So if the REPO_ROOT format is
file based do a full clone.

Change-Id: Ic03af1e55b41a97790de478563100247c37065ab
"}]
commit_message:
Don't shallow clone from file:// in integration test

Shallow cloning ends up writing a temporary file in the source git repo,
but we may not have write access to it. So if the REPO_ROOT format is
file based do a full clone.

Change-Id: Ic03af1e55b41a97790de478563100247c37065ab

messages:

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-hacking-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/02/151302/1/check/gate-hacking-python26/2cfbef3/ : SUCCESS in 27s
- gate-hacking-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/02/151302/1/check/gate-hacking-pep8/146eba0/ : SUCCESS in 30s
- gate-hacking-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/02/151302/1/check/gate-hacking-docs/ffe0bf1//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 28s
- gate-hacking-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/02/151302/1/check/gate-hacking-python27/3136550/ : SUCCESS in 32s
- gate-hacking-python33 http://logs.openstack.org/02/151302/1/check/gate-hacking-python33/04b3cdb/ : SUCCESS in 1m 32s
- gate-hacking-pypy http://logs.openstack.org/02/151302/1/check/gate-hacking-pypy/6cfe2e6/ : SUCCESS in 1m 10s
- gate-hacking-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/02/151302/1/check/gate-hacking-python34/4fd33e1/ : SUCCESS in 2m 14s (non-voting)
- gate-hacking-integration-nova http://logs.openstack.org/02/151302/1/check/gate-hacking-integration-nova/626c09c/ : SUCCESS in 1m 04s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2015-01-29 16:47:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

LGTM, I'm curious why flake8 didn't catch that?"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-01-29 17:18:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Commit message is too vague, can you be more specific. Also what version of pep8?'}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2015-01-29 23:33:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think either pep8 1.5.7 or master reports this.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-01-29 23:43:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Since hacking doesn't use pep8 1.5.7 yet, no reason to fix this until we gate on it."}, {'account_id': 12022, 'date': '2015-01-30 09:50:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't understand why gate didn't caught that.

But, from my point of view, it's important to let people use tox and succeed with it.

I use pep8 1.5.7 : if the problem is there, maybe we must change requirements."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-02-25 22:53:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

the gate didn't catch it because we are still not using pep8 1.5.7 yet. So running tox will work, most likely you just need to use '-r' and rebuild your env"}, {'account_id': 12022, 'date': '2015-02-26 09:56:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, I'm confused :

The requirements.txt file contains : "pep8==1.5.7"
Running tox with "-r" option return exactly the same result.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-02-26 19:53:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

sorry you are correct, we are using 1.5.7,  but because the gate isn't catching this we shouldn't fix it.  The whole point of hacking is to not have humans worry about this type of style issue.

I am interested in figuring out how you see this issue but myself and the gate don't see it."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-05-12 23:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

No activity on this in 3 months. abandoning, but feel free to restore this'}]

Fix E211 error

subject: Add import check for try/except wrapped imports
messages:
[{'account_id': 1054, 'date': '2014-11-13 16:44:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1054, 'date': '2014-11-13 16:47:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

This is more at a proposal stage than ready for acceptance.

Is this something people would be interested in adding? I've had a few reviews where it's been indicated that there is a rule that try/except imports should definitely go after all others.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/106617/11/git_review/tests/test_unit.py

Seems like it would be worth codifying this, if that's the case."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-13 16:58:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGit#Test_Failures

- gate-hacking-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/88/134288/1/check/gate-hacking-pep8/92810a1 : FAILURE in 22s
- gate-hacking-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/88/134288/1/check/gate-hacking-docs/ed5c61c/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 40s
- gate-hacking-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/88/134288/1/check/gate-hacking-python27/487bd04 : FAILURE in 25s
- gate-hacking-python33 http://logs.openstack.org/88/134288/1/check/gate-hacking-python33/574948d : FAILURE in 1m 50s
- gate-hacking-pypy http://logs.openstack.org/88/134288/1/check/gate-hacking-pypy/7d398cd : FAILURE in 53s
- gate-hacking-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/88/134288/1/check/gate-hacking-python26/93c6ee1 : FAILURE in 25s
- gate-hacking-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/88/134288/1/check/gate-hacking-python34/90ccb64 : FAILURE in 2m 00s (non-voting)
- gate-hacking-integration-nova http://logs.openstack.org/88/134288/1/check/gate-hacking-integration-nova/3ca9b76 : SUCCESS in 42s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2014-11-13 17:35:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Do you think there is a need to codify this? This is a fairly rare case so I am inclined to say don't add a rule for this."}, {'account_id': 1054, 'date': '2014-11-26 18:24:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Seems to occur a few times. I've ended up in discussions a few times where the debate was over what the correct style should be.

The precise style that's used does seem to vary across projects, so to head off debates on what's the standard I was proposing this as a possible codification of the style to avoid unnecessary discussion.

Hopefully either this is the correct approach and it can be applied, or it's identified as not the correct style and I can point future discussion to this review, even if it's not accepted in the end."}, {'account_id': 1054, 'date': '2014-11-26 18:24:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1054, 'date': '2014-11-26 18:25:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-26 18:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-11-13 16:44:45.000000000', 'message': 'Add import check for try/except wrapped imports

Try/except wrapped imports where alternative action to import either a
library from a different group should come after all other import
groups.

Example would be to fail on attempting to import a standard library that
is part of newer python versions, and instead need to fall back to a
third party library for compatibility.

Currently this appears to be the standard style adopted by most
OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: If7d867bdcd758375e167682dc69f49a9a0bce59d
'}, {'created': '2014-11-26 18:24:29.000000000', 'message': 'Add import check for try/except wrapped imports

Try/except wrapped imports where alternative action to import either a
library from a different group should come after all other import
groups.

Example would be to fail on attempting to import a standard library that
is part of newer python versions, and instead need to fall back to a

'}]
commit_message:
Add import check for try/except wrapped imports

Try/except wrapped imports where alternative action to import either a
library from a different group should come after all other import
groups.

Example would be to fail on attempting to import a standard library that
is part of newer python versions, and instead need to fall back to a
third party library for compatibility.

Change-Id: If7d867bdcd758375e167682dc69f49a9a0bce59d

commit_message:
install: suse: Update neutron service name

Update the service names under neutron section. For suse based releases
the packages are named as 'openstack-$project-*.service'

Change-Id: I1b6ae0ae2ef39d50a89813930d4eda587c346808

commit_message:
Enhance Manage Service with service-stack and vice-versa

Retrieves IN_PROGRESS stacks and resources being handled in
the given heat-engine and vice-versa.

commit_message:
Seed a functional test suite with a basic health check

This creates a base functional test suite with a minimal health check
of the service VM.  We can fill this in with richer tests as we go, but
in the meantime this will give us something to at least test that devstack
deployments and image builds produce a reachable VM via its management
port.

Change-Id: I304718e8d3cb270b1ff3b5ad46a027facb42f2af

Starting supervisord starts nailgun app too early
before it is ready to serve requests. It will be
started later in the docker container in the
foreground. This prevents a race condition where

Closes-Bug: #1453400

commit_message:
Inhibit start of supervisord for nailgun

Starting supervisord starts nailgun app too early
before it is ready to serve requests. It will be
started later in the docker container in the
foreground. This prevents a race condition where
DB upgrade takes place and nailgun is stopped.

Change-Id: Icd27758f00e8f472041eb83019cb89dcb030afd1
Closes-Bug: #1453400

commit_message:
Adds Hyper-V vNic hot-plug implementation

The new Hyper-V version adds support for adding and removing
vNICs on a running instance.

This is a driver feature parity blueprint.

Implementation is straightforward and consists in providing the
virt driver's class attach_interface and detach_interface methods.

Implements: blueprint hyper-v-vnic-hot-plug

Change-Id: I14aba8b14b7036a09a8dde8235fd4345af4da510

commit_message:
Fixed a parameter issue for config drive files

The parameters passed to novaclient create for config drive
files and user data were incorrect.

Change-Id: Ic7e2a1a32600194959d0c02179bbb0986bfe1413

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for network_get_all_by_host

This patches removes db layer hard-code permission checks for
network_get_all_by_host.

It is called by the follow function:
  1. init_host, context is elevated.
  2. _periodic_update_dns, is periodic task
  3. update_dns it is call by
     network.manager.allocate_for_instance and
     nova.network.manager.add_fixed_ip_to_instance
     this is fixed by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/150687

Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part

Change-Id: I5c503005598d9299db330463b8ffaeb383377b37

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-15 14:13:07.000000000', 'message': 'Adds RemoteFX support to the Hyper-V driver

Blueprint: hyper-v-remotefx

Microsoft RemoteFX enhances the visual experience in RDP connections,
including providing access to virtualized instances of a physical GPU to
multiple guests running on Hyper-V.

In order to use RemoteFX in Hyper-V 2012 R2, one or more DirectX 11 capable
display adapters must be present and the RDS-Virtualization server feature
must be installed.

This patch enables RemoteFX on Hyper-V Server / Windows Server 2012 R2
and above.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I91fabd5bce2564d48957e8aec1e50ff2625e5747

Microsoft RemoteFX enhances the visual experience in RDP connections,
including providing access to virtualized instances of a physical GPU to
multiple guests running on Hyper-V.

In order to use RemoteFX in Hyper-V 2012 R2, one or more DirectX 11 capable
display adapters must be present and the RDS-Virtualization server feature

commit_message:
Adds RemoteFX support to the Hyper-V driver

Blueprint: hyper-v-remotefx

Microsoft RemoteFX enhances the visual experience in RDP connections,
including providing access to virtualized instances of a physical GPU to
multiple guests running on Hyper-V.

In order to use RemoteFX in Hyper-V 2012 R2, one or more DirectX 11 capable
display adapters must be present and the RDS-Virtualization server feature
must be installed.

This patch enables RemoteFX on Hyper-V Server / Windows Server 2012 R2
and above.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I91fabd5bce2564d48957e8aec1e50ff2625e5747

[{'created': '2015-05-12 21:16:06.000000000', 'message': "Make neutron-lbaas-dsvm-api non-voting.

This job is broken.  A patch merged into neutron which breaks this job
because this job isn't actually using the neutron patch it's testing
against:

    https://review.openstack.org/#q,8db41f04d54526104920f3a160203ecf7ef453b0,n,z

The revert of that patch won't merge because the lbaas-dsvm-api job is
installing neutron master.

    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/182413/1

This job should be non-voting until it's fixed to properly test the
right neutron patch(es) instead of neutron master.

Change-Id: Ieca799e069696b460aef8caebda84428643ee259
"}]
commit_message:
Make neutron-lbaas-dsvm-api non-voting.

This job is broken.  A patch merged into neutron which breaks this job
because this job isn't actually using the neutron patch it's testing
against:

    https://review.openstack.org/#q,8db41f04d54526104920f3a160203ecf7ef453b0,n,z

The revert of that patch won't merge because the lbaas-dsvm-api job is
installing neutron master.

    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/182413/1

This job should be non-voting until it's fixed to properly test the
right neutron patch(es) instead of neutron master.

Change-Id: Ieca799e069696b460aef8caebda84428643ee259

commit_message:
Adds Hyper-V OVS ViF driver

This branch adds a new ViF driver to the Nova Hyper-V compute driver.
It's responsible for creating the OVS port and the related association
with the Hyper-V virtual switch port. Aside from the openvswitch binaries
it has no other dependencies. Flow rules are added by an external agent
such as OpenDaylight or by a Neutron OVS agent.

Change-Id: I4cee52f65968fa503f2c8a2c9a206489719fb15a
Implements: blueprint hyper-v-ovs-vif

commit_message:
Add functional test job for python-heatclient

Create functional test job for python-heatclient, set as non-voting
until its working. The heatclient functional tests will come from the tempest
cli tests.

Change-Id: Ib6338cdcce3e14ca9191fdc0d1f05e3d2d814125

commit_message:
Add --os-endpoint-type to match other services

Cinder uses the parameter '--endpoint-type' but other services
 (Glance, Nova, Swift) use '--os-endpoint-type'. (Neutron has deprecated
 'endpoint-type' in favor or 'os-endpoint-type' as well.
'--endpoint-type' should be deprecated and 'os-endpoint-type' should
be added.

Change-Id: I0ac6573be35c86b9f764a39f1e60486d2345f51b
Closes-Bug: #1453901

commit_message:
Add experimental glance_store functional test job

This adds a test job to run glance_store functional tests with the
filesystem driver. After this is up and running, jobs will be added for
each driver we want to functionally test as they become ready.

Change-Id: Ie4d06a6e2713f8d5b12582b2963271f10970672e

subject: Split SLA to base and plugins

commit_message:
Split SLA to base and plugins

Move all subclasses of SLA under plugins/sla
Split sla-plugins to modules

Implements: blueprint split-plugins
Change-Id: Icdc895fb829809944791fb48edb8e1f83a1f6bf0

- check-swiftclient-dsvm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/93/178793/2/check/check-swiftclient-dsvm-functional/4b27276/ : SUCCESS in 17m 11s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2015-05-07 16:55:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Took me a while to reproduce the bug - it does not manifest with simplejson which is the 'preferred' import!!

Makes sense, +1 for now because I could do with some reassurance that we are not undoing the fix applied in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/149043/ by bypassing read() and calling text. I don't *think* there is a problem because text consumes all of the raw underlying response content and comments suggest that raw then closes its connection.

I also need to work through the tests with a non-simplejson py3 env just to be sure - I think upstream jenkins does install simplejson.

IDK if we need to somehow make our tests run with and without simplejson??"}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2015-05-12 05:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Yeah but see, the problem is not with the raw closing the socket, it's with the urllib3's pool. In any case, something doesn't add up here. Tim decided not to change head_account and head_container here for some reason, and the log message suggests that he missed that we substitute read(), where it says "mocking the response".'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2015-05-12 17:41:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1 Workflow-1

*facepalm*

That's what I get for playing around with python3 without doing `pip3 install python-swiftclient`... actually installing requirements for python3 resolved it. Never mind."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2015-05-12 17:42:30.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

*facepalm*

That's what I get for playing around with python3 without doing `pip3 install python-swiftclient`... actually installing requirements for python3 resolved it. Never mind."}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2015-05-12 21:44:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Don't let it deter you though, we're fully onboard with supporting py3."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-29 18:26:37.000000000', 'message': "Actually function under python 3

Previously, we would pass raw bytes to json.loads, causing a TypeError
under python 3. This would prevent getting server capabilities, listing
accounts, listing containers, and cleaning up SLOs on overwrites.
Additionally, our tests missed the error by improperly mocking the
requests library.

Now, when calling json.loads, we'll either:
 * let the requests library detect and decode the body for us, by using
   Response.text, or
 * for SLO manifests, decode the response body ourselves. We do this
   because get_object *should* return a byte stream, and we know the
   server used UTF-8.

Further, the tests are cleaned up such that fake responses have bodies
that are always bytes and a text property that will decode those bytes
as UTF-8.

Change-Id: Ibc62d7bf52755b97c707c2cb4dd0f4ea41a7281e
"}, {'created': '2015-04-30 19:18:52.000000000', 'message': "Actually function under python 3

Previously, we would pass raw bytes to json.loads, causing a TypeError
under python 3. This would prevent getting server capabilities, listing
accounts, listing containers, cleaning up SLOs on overwrites, and
uploading with --skip-identical to an existing SLO.  Additionally, our
tests missed the error by improperly mocking the requests library.

Now, when calling json.loads, we'll either:
 * let the requests library detect and decode the body for us, by using
   Response.text, or
 * for SLO manifests, decode the response body ourselves. We do this
   because get_object *should* return a byte stream, and we know the
   server used UTF-8.

Further, the tests are cleaned up such that fake responses have bodies
that are always bytes and a text property that will decode those bytes
as UTF-8.

Change-Id: Ibc62d7bf52755b97c707c2cb4dd0f4ea41a7281e
"}]
commit_message:
Actually function under python 3

Previously, we would pass raw bytes to json.loads, causing a TypeError
under python 3. This would prevent getting server capabilities, listing
accounts, listing containers, cleaning up SLOs on overwrites, and
uploading with --skip-identical to an existing SLO.  Additionally, our
tests missed the error by improperly mocking the requests library.

Now, when calling json.loads, we'll either:
 * let the requests library detect and decode the body for us, by using
   Response.text, or
 * for SLO manifests, decode the response body ourselves. We do this
   because get_object *should* return a byte stream, and we know the
   server used UTF-8.

Further, the tests are cleaned up such that fake responses have bodies
that are always bytes and a text property that will decode those bytes
as UTF-8.

Change-Id: Ibc62d7bf52755b97c707c2cb4dd0f4ea41a7281e

commit_message:
Add functional test job for python-muranoclient

Create functional test job for python-muranoclient, set as non-voting until
its working. The muranoclient functional tests are being extracted from the
main murano tempest-based tests.

Change-Id: I525a53222837c42790268e00d4408abaa99a2efb

commit_message:
Added NPM-based unit tests for merlin

This adds an npm-run based unit test run. It's effectively identical
to the js-test build.

Change-Id: I3ba979ace5c7536fda21424634b7fc300343aeb8
Depends-on: Ia487e8d21f18f9ac44fc14da2011ab60ef6d5a4f

commit_message:
NPM-Run jobs are now voting.

At the moment, StoryBoard is the only project using these builds,
and they've been passing for a while now. In order to deprecate
the old tox-based javascript builds, we are switching these
to voting builds.

Change-Id: I4b4214ecebf13fd2ef6361045d20761ecc880481

[{'created': '2015-05-08 22:10:17.000000000', 'message': 'Deal with yum --downloadonly CentOS 6.x quirks

Some packages may depend on python-setuptools, which is not
installed and cannot be reinstalled on CentOS 6.x once yum has
erased them, so use --skip-broken to avoid aborting. Also on this
platform --downloadonly causes yum to return nonzero even when it
succeeds, so ignore its exit code.

commit_message:
Deal with yum --downloadonly CentOS 6.x quirks

Some packages may depend on python-setuptools, which is not
installed and cannot be reinstalled on CentOS 6.x once yum has
erased them, so use --skip-broken to avoid aborting. Also on this
platform --downloadonly causes yum to return nonzero even when it
succeeds, so ignore its exit code.

Change-Id: Iaada39ae81e1e47fe9d0bedba80fd19e4e0e6f38

[{'created': '2015-05-09 21:42:06.000000000', 'message': 'Remove custom taskflow sqlalchemy environments

These environments have not actually turned up anything
since they have existed, so I think it is fine to discard
them and let the main python environments sqlalchemy versions
that are tested continue to be used going forward.

Change-Id: I0e7b67985e24134f0695857062525fedc9fe18c1
'}, {'created': '2015-05-11 19:06:38.000000000', 'message': 'Remove custom taskflow sqlalchemy environments

These environments have not actually turned up anything
since they have existed, so I think it is fine to discard
them and let the main python environments sqlalchemy versions
that are tested continue to be used going forward.

Change-Id: I0e7b67985e24134f0695857062525fedc9fe18c1

commit_message:
Remove custom taskflow sqlalchemy environments

These environments have not actually turned up anything
since they have existed, so I think it is fine to discard
them and let the main python environments sqlalchemy versions
that are tested continue to be used going forward.

Change-Id: I0e7b67985e24134f0695857062525fedc9fe18c1

commit_message:
Add new config option to globally trigger resource validation

This commit adds a new config option to the config group to trigger
all the validation code. It also deprecates the run_ssh option in the
compute group since this will eventually be used globally. The intent
of this option is so that it will trigger both the creation of any
validation resources as well as used as run_ssh was originally
intended, to trigger ssh into nodes when needed.

Closes-Bug: #1453936
Partially-Implements: bp ssh-auth-strategy
Change-Id: I7d04f81457fc564ed82872e602746c8162fef24c

Would appreciate Eric's review on this."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2015-05-11 19:24:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

Just re-read this (using as a model for similar changes
to generic NFS) and saw that reserved_percentage will
be always reported up to the scheduler as 0, irrespective
of the value of cfg.reserved_percentage.

Is that really what is wanted?

The main spec your are implmenting states:

reserved_percentage: This is an existing parameter. It represents the percentage of backend capacity that is reserved. It ranges from 0 to 100. Default is 0. Note this refers to the real capacity. This is per backend
or per pool depending on driver implementation.'}, {'account_id': 14428, 'date': '2015-05-11 19:45:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

@Tom Barron,

Good point. Since long back we are sending "reserved_percentage" as 0, irrespective of cfg.reserved_percentage value of driver.

But this patch is specific to "over subscription in thin provisioning" parameters.

I will send another patch to use "cfg.reserved_percentage" value for reserved_percentage.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2015-05-11 19:51:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1

With the understanding that there will be a followup
patch for reserved percentage, this (once again) looks
good to me.'}, {'account_id': 14428, 'date': '2015-05-11 19:52:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

commit_message:
GlusterFS: Support over subscription in thin provisioning

This patch adds "over subscription in thin provisioning" support to
GlusterFS driver.

The following changes are proposed:
* GlusterFS driver reports the following new capacities and ratios:
  * provisioned_capacity
  * max_over_subscription_ratio
  * thin_provisioning_support (True or False)
  * thick_provisioning_support (True or False)

Co-Authored-By: Deepak C Shetty <deepakcs@redhat.com>
Implements: blueprint glusterfs-over-subscription-thin-provisioning
Change-Id: I7fbbe989c865dce42102b63f7d52a8edb63e7a9e

You get the correctness benefits of the caching scheduler, but without some of the downsides (and without the big performance boost by reducing the calls to the scheduler).

Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-05-11 20:32:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Patch Set 38 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-05-11 20:43:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 39: Code-Review-1

As mentioned on the bug report, I actually don't believe this can happen, or at least, as described in the bug report and with the filter scheduler and default host manager.

The default host manager, upon every call to select_destinations() -- which is the same regardless of whether you launch one or more than one instance -- completely refreshes its HostState object list with a call to the database to get ALL compute node records:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/host_manager.py#L535

The database has the freshest information possible. The select_destinations() call returns a set of hosts. The length of that set of returned host state objects is compared to the length of requested instances, and if it less, a NoValidHost is raised. This will trigger a completely new call to select_destinations() eventually, which will read all new compute node objects from the DB.

Perhaps there is something in the caching scheduler that is throwing this off?

-jay"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-11 23:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Verified+1

Actually host_manager read all the compute_nodes from DB during every scheduling request, but not all the HostStates have chance to been refreshed because of the below logic.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/host_manager.py#L185

The updated time of HostState was reset at HostState.consume_from_instance. 

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/host_manager.py#L254

So if the multiple-create failed, and the resource of selected_hosts didn't change, the HostState.updated always was greater than compute_node.updated_at. 

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L592

The resource leaking happened, at the worst case, we must restart the nova-scheduler in order to release it."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-05-12 13:29:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Code-Review+2

OK, Rui, thanks for pointing that out. I see now what you are talking about.

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2015-05-12 14:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2015-05-12 19:32:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-12 19:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: -Verified

commit_message:
Fix scheduler issue when multiple-create failed

If multiple creating failed, set the updated time of
selected HostState to None so that these HostStates are
refreshed according to database in next schedule, and
release the resource consumed by instance in the process
of selecting host.

Change-Id: I70b3272b7dc3d29f39bd8c2d8fed362cf497c887
Closes-Bug: #1408859

After netconfig completes it's possible that the host lost access to
the repo's needed to install packages. We will check that we can access

commit_message:
Add check_repo_access to verify network after netconfig

After netconfig completes it's possible that the host lost access to
the repo's needed to install packages. We will check that we can access
each repo in the repos list prior to attempting anything else.

Change-Id: Ifa73687fda2d84f7daa6303849e2c52fd2ba3780
Related-bug: #1261940

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-12 10:27:59.000000000', 'message': "Fix Ceph deployment on controller node combined with 'cinder-vmware' role

- Ceph granular deployment task tries to start 'cinder-backup' and
  'cinder-volume' services after execution of 'ceph' puppet class, but
  services fail to start, because needed init.d files are absent
  (appropriate packages are not installed); root cause of this failure
  is that 'openstack-cinder' task should check cinder-vmware role as last
  attempt, now if 'cinder-vmware' role is assigned to controller it
  changes execution code path that way that openstack-cinder configures
  VMDK backend instead of Ceph which installs needed packages
- remove 'cinder::volume::vmdk' class declaration out of
  'openstack::cinder' puppet class

Change-Id: Iaa78c80caaa6555350f6fb2acb034e010c70ddfd
Closes-bug: #1453082
"}]
commit_message:
Fix Ceph deployment on controller node combined with 'cinder-vmware' role

- Ceph granular deployment task tries to start 'cinder-backup' and
  'cinder-volume' services after execution of 'ceph' puppet class, but
  services fail to start, because needed init.d files are absent
  (appropriate packages are not installed); root cause of this failure
  is that 'openstack-cinder' task should check cinder-vmware role as last
  attempt, now if 'cinder-vmware' role is assigned to controller it
  changes execution code path that way that openstack-cinder configures
  VMDK backend instead of Ceph which installs needed packages
- remove 'cinder::volume::vmdk' class declaration out of
  'openstack::cinder' puppet class

Change-Id: Iaa78c80caaa6555350f6fb2acb034e010c70ddfd
Closes-bug: #1453082

commit_message:
Remove clouds.yaml from gitignore

I keep my clouds.yaml file in my .config directory and not in
the development area.  I'm not sure why we should ignore this.

Change-Id: I0d025e9d7007e183adb729251aa402f3c3826b1e

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-14 03:49:13.000000000', 'message': 'Defer interactive import

Importing cliff.interactive is expense time-wise because cmd2 is
expensive to import.  Defer the initial import until we know we
are going to interactive mode.

Static testing puts the savings around 50-60ms on my MacBook Air.

Change-Id: Ic76c2bef1cd6b82f453251f12f131771d0c0048b
'}]
commit_message:
Defer interactive import

Importing cliff.interactive is expense time-wise because cmd2 is
expensive to import.  Defer the initial import until we know we
are going to interactive mode.

Static testing puts the savings around 50-60ms on my MacBook Air.

Change-Id: Ic76c2bef1cd6b82f453251f12f131771d0c0048b

commit_message:
further updates to plugins documentation

This should bring the PLUGINS.rst document up to date with the current
implementation in the code. There are still things to design and say
about external from tree support, as well as the 'settings' file,
however this covers the resources.sh.

Change-Id: Id7e2e7db4f5160d9019d76717db356518bfb5931

section_networking-services.xml

commit_message:
Fixes issue where loadbalancer is None in flow

A task was saying it provided LOADBALANCER but it wasn't returning
anything, so it overwrote the LOADBALANCER with None.

Change-Id: I8274832b5bfbabdf29f2491a5a7591e0817f6345
Closes-Bug: #1453945

[{'created': '2015-05-10 16:56:05.000000000', 'message': "Creating keystone user on customer stats opt-in

For creating keystone user on customer stats opt-in we are using
astute 'execute_task' with type 'puppet'. Puppet granule
'workloads_collector.pp' used for it. Puppet manifest will be applied
only on primary-controllers of operational clusters.

If customer is opted-in to stats before cluster deployment - keystone
user will be created during deployment process without additional tasks
in the Nailgun.

On the opt-out action nothing is to be done by design.

Items of the change:

- Creating tasks on user creation added to the master node settings handler
- Task name 'create_stats_user' added
- Method for getting primary node added to the objects.Cluster
- Task CreateStatsUserTask for executing puppet manifest for creating stats user added
- Fake thread for processing astute 'execute_task' added
- Logging of the task CreateStatsUserTask into action_logs handled
- Extracted base test class for master node settings tests

commit_message:
Creating keystone user on customer stats opt-in

For creating keystone user on customer stats opt-in we are using
astute 'execute_task' with type 'puppet'. Puppet granule
'workloads_collector.pp' used for it. Puppet manifest will be applied
only on primary-controllers of operational clusters.

If customer is opted-in to stats before cluster deployment - keystone
user will be created during deployment process without additional tasks
in the Nailgun.

On the opt-out action nothing is to be done by design.

Items of the change:

- Creating tasks on user creation added to the master node settings handler
- Task name 'create_stats_user' added
- Method for getting primary node added to the objects.Cluster
- Task CreateStatsUserTask for executing puppet manifest for creating stats
  user added
- Fake thread for processing astute 'execute_task' added
- Logging of the task CreateStatsUserTask into action_logs handled
- Extracted base test class for master node settings tests
- Parameter for workloads username renamed from 'user' to 'username' in
  deployment orchestration. It is required for proper 'workloads_collector'
  granule processing

Change-Id: I7186bb485969c57789cd1e1cc588a8f7b8ba9917
Closes-Bug: #1452821

Hmm disk-image-create defaults to the same architecture as the host where it is being run on, see lib/common-defaults.

Regarding the actual fix, IMHO it should be better to add some 00-check-centos7 (and similar for -rhel7) root.d script, which would abort the generation if ARCH!="amd64".'}, {'account_id': 9268, 'date': '2015-04-27 11:40:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks Pino for the review. Indeed, $ARCH should already be correctly initialized. I realize the problem here is $NODE_ARCH, its default value is i386. And this value is passed to disk-image-create.

I will adjust my patch the way you suggest. This is definitively a better way to handle the situation.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-27 11:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
force arch amd64 for EL7 elements

rhel7 and centos7 images are both only available on x86_64 arch.
if $ARCH is misconfigured, some strange error will happen during the build.
For example, DIB will try to install EPEL i386 on the 64bit root system.

For the record, tripleo-incubator $NODE_ARCH default value is i386. The
problem will happend as soon as the default value is used with one of
these root elements.

This commit ensure the $ARCH is set to amd64 as soon as the centos7 or
rhel7 root element are used.

Change-Id: Ie41fa2da48eac6bf89b96cfa137c0f572dae6734

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Implement nova rescue

The root disk image is moved to a separate disk slot while the
rescue image will take it's place. If the instance requires it,
a temporary config drive is created as well.

Unrescuing the instance will move the root disk image back in
place, removing temporary images.

Implements: blueprint hyper-v-rescue

Change-Id: I6059ae35a77d675f54b98b2b43b5762e1d24365b

commit_message:
IBP: add cleanup for image building

This patch wraps image build procedure into
try-except-finally and appends some cleaning actions
into finally section. If something goes wrong during
image building, build environment will be cleaned up.
1) Stop running processes inside image chroot
2) Umount image chroot
3) Detach loop devices
4) Remove temporary files

Closes-Bug: #1451817
Partially implements: blueprint ibp-build-ubuntu-images
Change-Id: I7a7abf46f93fad3a3343dcf320781beec42f44bd

Forcibly changing the global defaults isn't the nicest thing to do
and turns out to be a pain during tests.  Make overriding defaults into
an arg to OpenStackConfig.__init__().

OSC is the only known user of set_default(), once this is released and
in global-requirements OSC an be updated then set_default() can be removed.

Change-Id: Iddbc66398e89f06f1d665d7b0ef243bc786c8e36
"}]
commit_message:
Change overriding defaults to kwarg

Forcibly changing the global defaults isn't the nicest thing to do
and turns out to be a pain during tests.  Make overriding defaults into
an arg to OpenStackConfig.__init__().

OSC is the only known user of set_default(), once this is released and
in global-requirements OSC an be updated then set_default() can be removed.

Change-Id: Iddbc66398e89f06f1d665d7b0ef243bc786c8e36

commit_message:
Update tags in projects.yaml based on validate_tags

Ran tools/validate_tags.py and update projects.yaml based on the results

* openstack/manila-ui should have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
* openstack/oslo.cache should not have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
  Ignoring since oslo.cache is a new library and will have stable
  branches (intent).
* openstack/pylockfile should not have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
* openstack/requirements should have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
* Trove should not have the tag 'team:diverse-affiliation'
  Two organizations represent >80% (80.70%) of any of the sum of all
  reviews done by core reviewers against patches submitted to any of the
  git repositories managed by the team
* openstack/python-keystoneclient-kerberos should not have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
* openstack/python-keystoneclient-saml2 should not have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
* Manila should have the tag 'team:diverse-affiliation'
* openstack/os-brick should not have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
* Infrastructure should not have the tag 'team:diverse-affiliation'
  51.32% (>50%) of reviews in past 6 months were from HP.
* openstack/congress should have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
* openstack/openstack-manuals should not have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'
  Ignored since has stable/juno just not Kilo
* openstack/python-openstackclient should have the tag 'release:has-stable-branches'

Raw output: http://paste.openstack.org/show/213948/

Change-Id: I4ffccbf3bd78ccc6c13ef8b8782f3f5aa5c8defe

commit_message:
Default username for stats collecting changed

Default username is changed from 'workloads_collector' to
'fuel_stats_user'.

Change-Id: Ibf4b520aaed305e707e22a294dce743e71ddfba7
Closes-Bug: #1454204

commit_message:
Add rabbitmq max_retries and retry_interval in nova.conf.erb

Oslo.message using rabbit_max_retries and rabbit_retry_interval to
define reconnect rabbitmq server times and interval when can not
connect to rabbitmq server.

Change-Id: Ie5ce28de16ed2b4b9c51a8b81e4accaca1466cac
Partial-bug: #1439968

[{'created': '2015-04-09 14:17:44.000000000', 'message': 'Remove the unneeded horizontal scrollbar

Even on really large screens, the horizontal scrollbar is shown. This is
because the `div.related` class has a width of 100% in basic.css and in
tweaks.css a border is also defined. This causes the div to be two pixes
wider than the screen.

Change-Id: I2881d8eca99988ff8372b22aecc1a1a90c66a314
'}]
commit_message:
Remove the unneeded horizontal scrollbar

Even on really large screens, the horizontal scrollbar is shown. This is
because the `div.related` class has a width of 100% in basic.css and in
tweaks.css a border is also defined. This causes the div to be two pixes
wider than the screen.

Change-Id: I2881d8eca99988ff8372b22aecc1a1a90c66a314

commit_message:
Add gerrit dashboard files

Move the gerrit-dash-creator input files to a repo where the Oslo team
can more easily manage them and add a tox environment with supporting
tools to build the dashboard URLs.

Change-Id: I9057ea3ae1d96ed1d122de72a00273c42c15f809

commit_message:
Remove timeutils.strtime() usage

This patch remove strtime() usage as it's going to be deprecated in
oslo_utils (see I8b5119e64369ccac3423dccc04421f99912df733).

Change-Id: Ida6f35d9c30e9b96370c62c56e1e2e2bd005ceea

[{'created': '2015-05-11 22:55:27.000000000', 'message': 'Add tests for OSC usage

OSC uses os-client-config as an intermediate handler in the
argparse-to-final-options sequence.
* Validate the expected usage of the argparse arguement to get_one_cloud().

commit_message:
Add tests for OSC usage

OSC uses os-client-config as an intermediate handler in the
argparse-to-final-options sequence.
* Validate the expected usage of the argparse arguement to get_one_cloud().

This turned out to be a problem with the way set_defaults() was implemented
and has been withdrawn until set_defaults is re-worked as a kwarg to
OpenStackCloud.__init__()
* Validate setting the default auth_type value

Change-Id: Idae91962f05d787cecf4a59fac01e9321bc69687

(4 comments)

The performance impact of porting is my biggest concern here. I don't think we should accept a blanket statement of "python3 is always faster" without data to support that. It will be a really big deal for our deployers if performance degrades because of a port -- think people needing to deploy new physical infrastructure to keep up with their workloads.

I'd like to see this spec explore how we can ensure performance isn't degrading as we do this work. That might be implemented in Rally, or something else.

We also need to discuss what happens to our older supported distros. Are we expecting RHEL to have a working python 3.4? Does it?'}, {'account_id': 12071, 'date': '2015-04-24 01:42:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The concern about performance is quite legitimate. Artificial benchmarks indicate that Python 3.4 is much slower than Python 2.7. Some solid Rally numbers really should be produced to back up the performance assertions in this proposal.

RHEL support for Python 3 is in RHSCL which only supports 3.3 at present.'}, {'account_id': 12071, 'date': '2015-04-24 04:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Apparently RHSC got Python 3.4 today.'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-04-24 08:19:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-24 08:21:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

- gate-nova-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/68/176868/2/check/gate-nova-specs-docs/4447cda//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 57s
- gate-nova-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/68/176868/2/check/gate-nova-specs-python27/70848a3/ : FAILURE in 1m 39s'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-04-24 08:23:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(11 comments)

> The performance impact of porting is my biggest concern here.

Ok. I updated the spec to elaborate this section. In short, there is no impact on performances, sorry!

See the updated spec for the details. I added a reference to a macrobenchmark.


> We also need to discuss what happens to our older supported distros. Are we expecting RHEL to have a working python 3.4? Does it?

RHEL7 doesn't come with Python 3, but Python 3.3 is available for RHEL6 and RHEL7 with SCL.

My spec targets Python 3.4 because we are now using Python 3.4 gates, but there is no major difference between Python 3.3 and 3.4. Code written for Python 3.4 should work on Python 3.3 (or would only require very small changes).

I don't think that it's the right time to discuss dropping Python 2 support. The first step is to port code. Linux vendors are well aware of Python 2.7 end of life (note: it was recently extended to 2020). For example, Fedora and Ubuntu are working on dropping Python 2 on their default install. RHEL is mostly based on Fedora, so enhancements will later be integrated into RHEL.


> Artificial benchmarks indicate that Python 3.4 is much slower than Python 2.7.

The answer is in the question: don't trust artificial microbenchmarks. I mentionned a *macro* benchmark in my updated spec."}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-04-24 08:25:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> This spec reminds me of another one ;) Thanks for taking care of this.

So first, we have lots of agreement here:

* lets be able to run Nova (unmodified) on python 3.4 and python 2.7 by the end of liberty
* success means tempest pass and unit tests pass

What we don't seem to agree on:

* when to drop python 2.7 support, we agree its not liberty, so lets not even consider that in this spec
* what to do about the dependencies that don't yet work on python 3.4, first we need to say thats actually still a bit of an issue, and while it seems easy to work around, we need to say what the plan is around python-mysql, which seems to be the biggest sticking point right now."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-04-30 09:38:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Uploaded patch set 9.

Changes:

* Rephrase "Proposed change" to better explain the status of dependencies
* Replace the long rationale with a link to the "Why should OpenStack move to Python 3 right now?" article
* Don't discuss if or when we should stop supporting Python 2: just say "Python 2 support is kept."
* Remove the "Drop Python 2 support" alternative
* Remove the "update nova devref" work item (other doc will be completed, but I consider that it's out of the scope of the Nova spec)
* Specify what "Nova tests" stands for: write "unit tests" instead of just "tests", add more work items for the Nova functional tests, and explicitly exclude Tempest tests from the scope of the spec
* Remove the work item related to dependencies (it's not directly related to the nova spec)
* Rewrite the "Other deployer impact" section
* Add a blueprint tag to the commit message

For Tempest: I don't feel able to fix all Tempest tests. There are so many options (VMware, Hyper-V, Xen, etc.) for a single man. Vendors will have to help on specific code if they consider Python 3 important enough. Anyway, almost all Python 3 issues should already be covered by unit and functional tests. Somewhere, I should also cut the spec to fit into a single cycle. Otherwise, it may take too long to write all patches and get them merged. It doesn't mean that I will not help to fix Tempest tests ;-) It's just to have a well defined scope for the spec.'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-04-30 14:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2015-05-04 14:47:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/nova+branch:master+topic:bp/nova-python3,n,z

When these patches will be merged, it will become possible to write a subset of unit tests which pass on Python 3.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-05-05 13:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Thank you for your hard work re-drafting this, really close now I think.

I was assuming all tempest tests would be passing, to confirm your statement that the API will not be impacted by this move to run under py3.4

Sorry if my previous comments were a bit unclear, I was lumping functional and tempest tests into one big bucket in my head.

No need to be too specific about the jobs that get added, we can work with infra to work out the best way to test this, the important thing being they all pass when we run Nova with python3.4'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-05-05 15:56:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 9107, 'date': '2015-05-05 15:58:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-01 15:00:03.000000000', 'message': "Remove unnecessary force_tenant_isolation

The existing use of force_tenant_isolation seems to have been based on this
bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1252971. We no longer have that
issue since there is no XML version, but I'm not sure why it was needed even
then if running tempest in a valid way. If tenant isolation is on then there
is no need. If not, then you are running serially, and there is no issue, or
you are using test accounts in which case there is also no issue.

Change-Id: I8bce43c73538128d530688f1e3c8ac9a0c119e68
"}, {'created': '2015-05-01 15:08:09.000000000', 'message': "Remove unnecessary force_tenant_isolation

The existing use of force_tenant_isolation seems to have been based on this
bug 1252971. We no longer have that
issue since there is no XML version, but I'm not sure why it was needed even
then if running tempest in a valid way. If tenant isolation is on then there
is no need. If not, then you are running serially, and there is no issue, or
you are using test accounts in which case there is also no issue.

Related-Bug: #1252971

Change-Id: I8bce43c73538128d530688f1e3c8ac9a0c119e68
"}]
commit_message:
Remove unnecessary force_tenant_isolation

The existing use of force_tenant_isolation seems to have been based on this
bug 1252971. We no longer have that
issue since there is no XML version, but I'm not sure why it was needed even
then if running tempest in a valid way. If tenant isolation is on then there
is no need. If not, then you are running serially, and there is no issue, or
you are using test accounts in which case there is also no issue.

Related-Bug: #1252971

Change-Id: I8bce43c73538128d530688f1e3c8ac9a0c119e68

commit_message:
Allow loading custom config files into Config Fixture.

This patch adds a set_config_files option that allows a tester to
force load a specific list of configuration files. It will override the
existing set of files, and trigger a reload of those configuration
files.

Note: This _does_ trigger the autodetection mechanism, as the
present state of oslo_config makes it so __call__ is the only thing
that sets self._args. After triggering, however, it immediately
overrides the detected file list and replaces it with the provided one.

Tests provided.

Change-Id: I0bcea8be9d2527c61bd8d150e9ed606fabdd290e

As for old ones, upgrade may be an issue since the switch would require update to sudoers file and configuration files, among other things, so may be not worth the benefit."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-04-16 13:44:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

I obviously considered that when we created oslo.rootwrap and decided it was not worth the pain it creates.

Basically we have sudoers everywhere allowing "nova-rootwrap" which will need to be updated to "oslo-rootwrap" before we can phase out nova-rootwrap. You force a painful config file change on packagers and ops for... what gain ? A few octets of disk space in corner cases ? This microscopic file is only duplicated on nodes that happen to run Cinder and Nova. If Nova could completely ignore rootwrap I'd say that would be worth it, but it has to ship the rootwrap.conf and filter files anyway.'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2015-04-24 16:14:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Thiery

This change doesn't force us to switch to oslo-rootwrap binary in existing projects, but provides such alternative. For example, new deployments might want to use it. On the other hand, for projects that want to use rootwrap there won't be any surprise about the fact that you need to provide your own endpoint even given the fact that it directly points to the code from other project.

And one more thought. If oslo.rootwrap would provide its own endpoint, we won't have to trust other packages to call it directly and not call any of their own code there."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2015-04-29 11:36:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Ack, makes sense as an additional thing'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2015-04-29 14:56:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2015-04-29 14:57:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Generate a oslo-rootwrap console script

Currently projects like nova, cinder, neutron etc are generating
their own project-rootwrap script, but they are just copies of each
other as we send the configuration file as a parameter. So we should
generate a script in oslo.rootwrap itself and get rid of others
over a period of time. In this change, we also add a script for the
daemon mode.

Change-Id: I9e9033fbf61161149e586098e4a60b9522ec5437

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-03-31 15:50:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix logging of deprecated opts with dest override

When a deprecated opt is used and the new opt name has the dest
property overridden, we were logging the dest property instead of
the actual opt name in the deprecation warning.  This is confusing
because it leads to log messages such as:

Option "username" from group "nova" is deprecated. Use option
"username" from group "nova".

This is nonsense.  In this case the proper new name was "user-name"
but because it had a dest override of "username" that's what was
logged.

Because the deprecation check code does not have access to the
actual opt itself, we need to pass the undeprecated name down from
the opt into the namespace code that does the check.

I also tried simply adding a (group, name) tuple to the beginning
of the names list, but this subtly broke the CLI opt tests because
there are specific combinations of - and _ variants expected, and
this seems to violate those assumptions.  I did not pursue it any
further because I felt it was better to simply be explicit about
the current name and not mess around with adding non-existent opt
names to the lookup list solely for logging purposes.

Change-Id: Ib1ea8ae2d60a9c508935bad27d7ddc2cdb5ab505
Closes-Bug: #1438314
'}]
commit_message:
Fix logging of deprecated opts with dest override

When a deprecated opt is used and the new opt name has the dest
property overridden, we were logging the dest property instead of
the actual opt name in the deprecation warning.  This is confusing
because it leads to log messages such as:

Option "username" from group "nova" is deprecated. Use option
"username" from group "nova".

This is nonsense.  In this case the proper new name was "user-name"
but because it had a dest override of "username" that's what was
logged.

Because the deprecation check code does not have access to the
actual opt itself, we need to pass the undeprecated name down from
the opt into the namespace code that does the check.

I also tried simply adding a (group, name) tuple to the beginning
of the names list, but this subtly broke the CLI opt tests because
there are specific combinations of - and _ variants expected, and
this seems to violate those assumptions.  I did not pursue it any
further because I felt it was better to simply be explicit about
the current name and not mess around with adding non-existent opt
names to the lookup list solely for logging purposes.

Change-Id: Ib1ea8ae2d60a9c508935bad27d7ddc2cdb5ab505
Closes-Bug: #1438314

Use optimized config for RabbitMQ cluster

Use some optimized configuration settings for RabbitMQ when
clustered. Data is ported from Astapor.

See mailing-list discussion [1] but I'm not in favor of splitting the code here.
I understand the code will be merged but I would like to highlight this it not the way to write Puppet manifests and how we want to use Hiera. I know everyone knows these thoughts, but this comments allows me to track it somewhere.

Thank you Dan to move forward with that, but I really hope we will get back to the proper way in a next round.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063527.html"}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2015-05-12 13:48:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

I'll hold off my +2 for a while, re-add it if we decide we really need to go this way."}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2015-05-12 14:35:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Puppet: Split out controller pacemaker manifest

This patch adds support for using the Heat resource registry
so that end users can enable pacemaker. Using this approach
allows us to isolate all of the pacemaker logic for the
controller in a single template rather than use conditionals
for every service that must support it.

Change-Id: Ibefb80d0d8f98404133e4c31cf078d729b64dac3

commit_message:
Remove tox py33 environment no longer used

This py33 environment is no longer being tested
with in an automated fashion (since the py34 environment
replaces it) so we should just remove it from the tox
ini file.

Change-Id: I3a4040b8a3c656b93b7e0ff2c20bed4119ac7c74

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/180322/2/network/ports/service_map.yaml

We use this file to assign each individual service to a particular network. This gives us fine grained control over which network we place each API.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2015-05-09 12:08:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-05-09 12:08:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified+1

commit_message:
Add a service ports to network mapping resource

This patch adds an initial version of a service mapping resource
which can be used to associate individual service bind addresses
for OpenStack to a network. As an intial example only the
Neutron tunneling network has been added.

The goal is to use this data construct in each role
template to obtain the correct network for each
service.

Change-Id: I9665025726f69ec1cd838a28de61e3ddd8f56e12

This also adds in a TODO hack required to bypass a current
issue in eventlet (where importing eventlet from threads does
not work correctly) so that the jobboard producer/consumer
example works correctly (we should remove this hack in the

Change-Id: I28b9ff575fec3894892989c021c8a9c6a1a97f66
'}]
commit_message:
Add eventlet>=0.17.1 to py34 environment

This also adds in a TODO hack required to bypass a current
issue in eventlet (where importing eventlet from threads does
not work correctly) so that the jobboard producer/consumer
example works correctly (we should remove this hack in the
future when able to).

Change-Id: I28b9ff575fec3894892989c021c8a9c6a1a97f66

commit_message:
Add functional post test_hook

This is an initial add of a simple post_test_hook for the
functional tests that are run in cinderclient.

Change-Id: I0b25522b0b133a94f9804390fd96827077ed4abf

Looks like it's better to download image once and make it public for all tenants."}, {'account_id': 7132, 'date': '2015-04-09 13:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

As or uploading the image to each tenant: Since Juno introduced policy.json ACLs Glance api does not allow a _member_ user to make image public. The policy.json can be modified but in most of the installation it will be left with defaults and this allows only admin to make images public. This means that if you want to boot clusters in different tenants you need an image in each of them.'}, {'account_id': 7132, 'date': '2015-04-09 14:23:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 14817, 'date': '2015-04-09 14:44:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified+1

[Sahara] Improve Image context

The context now supports exisng images via 'image_uuid' parameter.

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-06 02:49:12.000000000', 'message': "Add support for container status

This patch implement two kinds of status for containers:

1. container status:
   1) ACTIVE: means container is exist in docker and can be used.
   2) ERROR: means container is not exist in docker or container is
             exist in docker but status is error.

2. container power state:
   1) Running: means container is running.
   2) Stopped: means container is stopped.
   3) Paused: means container is paused.

This patch don't timing sync the status with docker, it sync the status
only when the container-show api is called.

Change-Id: I6a5eea341ed507afb4895408b2e2ed429094785a
Implements: blueprint container-status

commit_message:
Add support for container status

This patch implements the status for containers:

   1) Error: means container is not exist in docker or container is
             exist in docker but status is error.
   2) Running: means container is running.
   3) Stopped: means container is stopped.
   4) Paused: means container is paused.

This patch don't timing sync the status with docker, it sync the status
only when the container-show api is called.

Change-Id: I6a5eea341ed507afb4895408b2e2ed429094785a
Implements: blueprint container-status

[{'account_id': 11097, 'date': '2014-05-07 08:59:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2014-05-07 08:59:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11097, 'date': '2014-08-13 10:33:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2014-09-03 05:03:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

A trunk port and the Neutron data model are fundamantally in disagreement here. By creating a port object that tags multiple VLANs that can belong to different networks, the 1:1 relationship between a Neutron Port and Neutron Network is violated. I don't think we should overload the port concept anymore for neutron and should instead introduce a new object type that carrys multiple network segments for use in NFV and other cases."}, {'account_id': 11097, 'date': '2014-09-03 09:04:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Could you describe your proposal more in detail?
The sub ports are the only ports (besides legacy normal ports) that connects to Neutron networks, and still only one network per port. The trunk ports attach to VMs and represents the NIC. The main idea of this model is to minimize impact on legacy model and code. Main part of change is related to VM to net connection. It should be possible to support this for future changes since the port is on both net and vm. And the feature can live its life on the side. There are other models that might be more tailor made for what I try to accomplish (like create separate NIC object, Allow Neutron port to connect to multiple networks), but many of them would spread further into neutron and affect more of neutron, be more visible to non feature users and be harder to support in the future. But there are other proposals (like Trunk network) that can be better or worse compared to the trunkport/subport proposal, depending on what you want to do.'}, {'account_id': 11097, 'date': '2014-09-04 03:10:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

In my reply above I state that only subports are connected to networks, but also the trunk port is connected to a network. It is connected to the network that will carry untagged traffic (from VM perspective).'}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2014-09-14 12:17:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think this would be a good topic for the summit since we are beyond Juno now anyway. I understand your point, but I don't agree that overloading the port concept would be easier to maintain than an extension that introduces a new trunk type."}, {'account_id': 11097, 'date': '2014-09-18 07:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Yes, I will propose this as a topic for the summit.
Some things do get easier. For example other code that tries to look at the ports at the network will find normal ports that contains familiar information. So far I have not made any change to DHCP code, it still works. Also topology viewer in Dashboard produces a usable picture, although it looks like the VM have many NICs connected to one networks each instead of one trunk NIC connected to many networks.'}, {'account_id': 11097, 'date': '2014-10-16 13:45:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11097, 'date': '2014-10-16 13:49:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 7249, 'date': '2014-10-16 13:54:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Please add import of neutron/db/trunk_port_db in neutron/db/migration/models/head for testing.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-10-16 15:00:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-05-07 08:59:42.000000000', 'message': "Trunk port support for VLAN ML2 type driver

WIP

Adds support to use VLAN tagged frames from VM when using the VLAN ML2
type driver. Extends port with 'trunkport:type', 'trunkport:parent_id' and
'trunkport:vid'. Type is either 'trunk' or 'subport'. If type is 'subport'
then parent_id shall be id of port with type 'trunk' and vid shall be
vid that VM uses to reach this subport. parent_id and vid shall be unset
for ports of type 'trunk'. Ports of type 'trunk' shall be argument to
nova when booting VM.

Implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
Change-Id: I9ceb9c22c7467c07f62fdd293d57b393b8a451e9
"}, {'created': '2014-05-07 19:46:04.000000000', 'message': "Trunk port support for VLAN ML2 type driver

commit_message:
Trunk port support for VLAN ML2 type driver, Server part

WIP

Adds support to use VLAN tagged frames from VM when using the ML2 plugin
with the openvswitch mechanism driver. Extends port with 'trunkport:type',
'trunkport:parent_id' and 'trunkport:vid'. Type is either 'trunk' or
'subport'. If type is 'subport' then parent_id shall be id of port with
type 'trunk' and vid shall be vid that VM uses to reach this
subport. parent_id and vid shall be unset for ports of type 'trunk'. Ports
of type 'trunk' shall be argument to nova when booting VM. This commit
contains the server part.

NFVImpact

Implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
Change-Id: I9ceb9c22c7467c07f62fdd293d57b393b8a451e9

commit_message:
Add instructions for removing OSDs to ops guide

OSDs must be manually removed from the Ceph cluster
before Fuel can delete them. The operations guide now
explains how to do that.

Change-Id: I7dc1e7d1f144a85bdf840ffbd655af929d1b72d4
Closes-bug: #1446089
Related-bug: #1428355

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-04-27 19:52:51.000000000', 'message': 'Add external genconfig calls

After moving to oslo.config we still were using
incubator config generator.  This was ok, but the
problem is we haven't been pulling config options
from the oslo libs.
This is a hack that just appends external lib calls
and appends those options to the sample file being built.

Note that we just put all oslo libs from the requirements
file in here.  Even those that may not have any config
options associated with them.  Additionally, naming of olso
libraries matters here, using the new "oslo_*" convention
results in the generator not finding any config options in
a number of the libs (ie concurrency).

Change-Id: Id76781e162c63e51aaf30a231b2d8271484cd711
Closes-Bug: #1447380
'}, {'created': '2015-04-27 20:39:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add external genconfig calls

Note that we just put all oslo libs from the requirements

Change-Id: Id76781e162c63e51aaf30a231b2d8271484cd711
Closes-Bug: #1447380
'}]
commit_message:
Add external genconfig calls

After moving to oslo.config we still were using
incubator config generator.  This was ok, but the
problem is we haven't been pulling config options
from the oslo libs.
This is a hack that just appends external lib calls
and appends those options to the sample file being built.

Note that we just put all oslo libs from the requirements
file in here.  Even those that may not have any config
options associated with them.  Additionally, naming of olso
libraries matters here, using the new "oslo_*" convention
results in the generator not finding any config options in
a number of the libs (ie concurrency).

Change-Id: Id76781e162c63e51aaf30a231b2d8271484cd711
Closes-Bug: #1447380

commit_message:
Have gate-ironic-python34 be a voting job

Since gate-ironic-python34 is working, have it run as a voting job in
both the check and gate queues.

Exclude stable branches for icehouse, juno, and kilo.

Change-Id: If32b6ef819d6b988b2c36361c95a14204c741067

commit_message:
Allow users to run 'tox -epy34'

With this commit, it is possible to successfully run 'tox -epy34', even though
only a small amount of tests will actually be run. This is a required step in
making Neutron compatible with Python 3, as described in the 'Porting to Python
3' specification.

This commit:
- fixes some broken imports, while making sure they still work with Python 3;
- updates a call to gettext.install;
- adds a py34 target in tox.ini.

Change-Id: I91cc7a992d05ea85f7004d1c5a45a1c02cbf1c85
Blueprint: neutron-python3

commit_message:
Merge lock/pause server tests between v2 and v2.1

Currently v2 and v2.1 have separate functional tests and their
corresponding sample files. As v2 and v2.1 are supposed to be identical,
there is overhead to maintain two set of functional tests and sample files.
We can have one set of tests which can run for both v2 and v2.1.

This commit merges servers actions lock/unlock, pause/unpause server
functional tests.

In V2.1 os-access-ip is separate plugin where in v2 it was mixed in server
plugin itself. So os-access-ip extension is enabled to run
merged functional tests for both v2 and v2.1.

Change-Id: I7e6c9d414959019eb6d29b2e87e1d8104c801903

commit_message:
Add function to log standard deprecated message

The standard deprecated message could only be generated using
a function wrapper, but sometimes it's useful to just log the
standard deprecated message.

A new function is added that generates the standard deprecated
message.

Change-Id: If4f5255a4579aa95188008637c23c724f43d24fa
Closes-Bug: 1448703

[{'created': '2015-04-28 01:48:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add flag for DEFROUTE=no in ifcfg files to ignore DHCP gateway

When multiple interfaces are configured with DHCP, and more than
one interface receives a gateway from the DHCP server(s), the
resulting default gateway on the system is unpredictable. This
change adds the "defroute" boolean to the configuration syntax
for os-net-config. Any interface type may be marked so that the
gateway received from the DHCP server will not be eligible as a
default gateway for the system. This only works for ifcfg files,
/etc/network/interfaces lacks an equivalent option.

commit_message:
Add flag for DEFROUTE=no in ifcfg files to ignore DHCP gateway

When multiple interfaces are configured with DHCP, and more than
one interface receives a gateway from the DHCP server(s), the
resulting default gateway on the system is unpredictable. This
change adds the "defroute" boolean to the configuration syntax
for os-net-config. Any interface type may be marked so that the
gateway received from the DHCP server will not be eligible as a
default gateway for the system. This only works for ifcfg files,
/etc/network/interfaces lacks an equivalent option.

Change-Id: Id775f3506b2ec60c9a2833efd49fb8319151c00d
Closes-Bug: 1449288

commit_message:
Add Rally job to Murano

This patch adds a non-voting Rally job to the Murano project.
It will be run on every check in Murano.

Change-Id: If098939d5766cb5605cdeaa7fc23f423ae476586
Depends-on: I58bd59889df51e5ec13d9135aa9a886a05a6efc0

commit_message:
Add Cloud Foundry application

 * Remove ubuntu14.04-x64-docker (replaced by Debian-based)
 * Add "Ubuntu 14.04 x64 (pre-installed murano-agent)" image
   used by Cloud Foundry application

Change-Id: I2fdd0403b8f0af7a24cba1e95139543bf69a56f9

commit_message:
Fix pep8 violations in tests

Some minor updates to the testing file so that it would pass a pep8
checker.  Also adds a pep8 tox target to test them :)

Change-Id: I5c704a1b5a1b5f8b6d80a8f538b56befbe656099

I like John's idea. That can resolve some of concern. @alex its interesting about the things it doesn't help with, but something is better than nothing.

I think they key thing to node, is clients that send the version should have the full validation, and at that point, the clients can sort out their code, at a timeframe that suits them."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-04-14 09:26:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

this is close, but I worry about the wording pasting us into a bad corner.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2015-04-16 11:38:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I agree with something is better than nothing :)

I have comment on John's spec https://review.openstack.org/#/c/173243/ about how I think about v2.1 with strong validation vs relax validation."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2015-05-03 21:51:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Add the description about v2.1 API validation

Nova v2.1 API has been implemented in Kilo, but the API contains
a concern about its strong input validation.
This patch adds the description about it for explaining what is
our standpoint.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I101239bbac785d5e8f06da3229b0191fffacbd80

commit_message:
add network info to the worlddump

This adds potentially helpful networking info to the world dump.

It also refactors some of the output mechanisms into reusable
functions for cleanliness in the code.

Change-Id: I39f95bd487c152925f8fadd1799149db35cffd52

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-05-07 17:14:38.000000000', 'message': 'Fix fip agent gateway port delete when migrating a fip

When associating a FloatingIP to a different private
fixed port in "hostB" without disassociating the existing
FloatingIP that is hosted in "hostA", the server does not
clean up the FloatingIP agent gateway port in "hostA" even
though if it is the last port that owns the floatingip.

This patch fixes the problem by checking if there is a host
change and if so it deletes the fip agent gateway port of
the old host, if there are no valid ports using the FloatingIP
in that host.

Change-Id: I038ac41cd74a54f63f749f1a9d498284b6c031c3
Closes-Bug: #1450982
'}]
commit_message:
Fix fip agent gateway port delete when migrating a fip

When associating a FloatingIP to a different private
fixed port in "hostB" without disassociating the existing
FloatingIP that is hosted in "hostA", the server does not
clean up the FloatingIP agent gateway port in "hostA" even
though if it is the last port that owns the floatingip.

This patch fixes the problem by checking if there is a host
change and if so it deletes the fip agent gateway port of
the old host, if there are no valid ports using the FloatingIP
in that host.

Change-Id: I038ac41cd74a54f63f749f1a9d498284b6c031c3
Closes-Bug: #1450982
